2052 return QGraphicsItem::CacheMode(d_ptr->cacheMode);
2053}
2054
2055/*!
2056 \since 4.4
2057 Sets the item's cache mode to \a mode.
2058
2059 The optional \a logicalCacheSize argument is used only by
2060 ItemCoordinateCache mode, and describes the resolution of the cache
2061 buffer; if \a logicalCacheSize is (100, 100), QGraphicsItem will fit the
2062 item into 100x100 pixels in graphics memory, regardless of the logical
2063 size of the item itself. By default QGraphicsItem uses the size of
2064 boundingRect(). For all other cache modes than ItemCoordinateCache, \a
2065 logicalCacheSize is ignored.
2066
2067 Caching can speed up rendering if your item spends a significant time
2068 redrawing itself. In some cases the cache can also slow down rendering, in
2069 particular when the item spends less time redrawing than QGraphicsItem
2070 spends redrawing from the cache.
2071
2072 When caching is enabled, an item's paint() function will generally draw into an
2073 offscreen pixmap cache; for any subsequent
2074 repaint requests, the Graphics View framework will redraw from the
2075 cache. This approach works particularly well with QGLWidget, which stores
2076 all the cache as OpenGL textures.
2077
2078 Be aware that QPixmapCache's cache limit may need to be changed to obtain
2079 optimal performance.
2080
2081 You can read more about the different cache modes in the CacheMode
2082 documentation.
2083
2084 \note Enabling caching does not imply that the item's paint() function will be
2085 called only in response to an explicit update() call. For instance, under
2086 memory pressure, Qt may decide to drop some of the cache information;
2087 in such cases an item's paint() function will be called even if there
2088 was no update() call (that is, exactly as if there were no caching enabled).
2089
2090 \sa CacheMode, QPixmapCache::setCacheLimit()
2091*/
2092void QGraphicsItem::setCacheMode(CacheMode mode, const QSize &logicalCacheSize)
2093{
2094 CacheMode lastMode = CacheMode(d_ptr->cacheMode);
2095 d_ptr->cacheMode = mode;
2096 bool noVisualChange = (mode == NoCache && lastMode == NoCache)
2097 || (mode == NoCache && lastMode == DeviceCoordinateCache)
2098 || (mode == DeviceCoordinateCache && lastMode == NoCache)
2099 || (mode == DeviceCoordinateCache && lastMode == DeviceCoordinateCache);
2100 if (mode == NoCache) {
2101 d_ptr->removeExtraItemCache();
2102 } else {
2103 QGraphicsItemCache *cache = d_ptr->extraItemCache();
2104
2105 // Reset old cache
2106 cache->purge();
2107
2108 if (mode == ItemCoordinateCache) {
2109 if (lastMode == mode && cache->fixedSize == logicalCacheSize)
2110 noVisualChange = true;
2111 cache->fixedSize = logicalCacheSize;
2112 }
2113 }
2114 if (!noVisualChange)
2115 update();
2116}
2117
2118/*!
2119 \since 4.6
2120
2121 Returns the modality for this item.
2122*/
2123QGraphicsItem::PanelModality QGraphicsItem::panelModality() const
2124{
2125 return d_ptr->panelModality;
2126}
2127
2128/*!
2129 \since 4.6
2130
2131 Sets the modality for this item to \a panelModality.
2132
2133 Changing the modality of a visible item takes effect immediately.
2134*/
2135void QGraphicsItem::setPanelModality(PanelModality panelModality)
2136{
2137 if (d_ptr->panelModality == panelModality)
2138 return;
2139
2140 PanelModality previousModality = d_ptr->panelModality;
2141 bool enterLeaveModal = (isPanel() && d_ptr->scene && isVisible());
2142 if (enterLeaveModal && panelModality == NonModal)
2143 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->leaveModal(item: this);
2144 d_ptr->panelModality = panelModality;
2145 if (enterLeaveModal && d_ptr->panelModality != NonModal)
2146 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->enterModal(item: this, panelModality: previousModality);
2147}
2148
2149/*!
2150 \since 4.6
2151
2152 Returns \c true if this item is blocked by a modal panel, false otherwise. If \a blockingPanel is
2153 non-zero, \a blockingPanel will be set to the modal panel that is blocking this item. If this
2154 item is not blocked, \a blockingPanel will not be set by this function.
2155
2156 This function always returns \c false for items not in a scene.
2157
2158 \sa panelModality(), setPanelModality(), PanelModality
2159*/
2160bool QGraphicsItem::isBlockedByModalPanel(QGraphicsItem **blockingPanel) const
2161{
2162 if (!d_ptr->scene)
2163 return false;
2164
2165
2166 QGraphicsItem *dummy = nullptr;
2167 if (!blockingPanel)
2168 blockingPanel = &dummy;
2169
2170 const QGraphicsScenePrivate *scene_d = d_ptr->scene->d_func();
2171 if (scene_d->modalPanels.isEmpty())
2172 return false;
2173
2174 // ###
2175 if (!scene_d->popupWidgets.isEmpty() && scene_d->popupWidgets.first() == this)
2176 return false;
2177
2178 for (int i = 0; i < scene_d->modalPanels.size(); ++i) {
2179 QGraphicsItem *modalPanel = scene_d->modalPanels.at(i);
2180 if (modalPanel->panelModality() == QGraphicsItem::SceneModal) {
2181 // Scene modal panels block all non-descendents.
2182 if (modalPanel != this && !modalPanel->isAncestorOf(child: this)) {
2183 *blockingPanel = modalPanel;
2184 return true;
2185 }
2186 } else {
2187 // Window modal panels block ancestors and siblings/cousins.
2188 if (modalPanel != this
2189 && !modalPanel->isAncestorOf(child: this)
2190 && commonAncestorItem(other: modalPanel)) {
2191 *blockingPanel = modalPanel;
2192 return true;
2193 }
2194 }
2195 }
2196 return false;
2197}
2198
2199#if QT_CONFIG(tooltip)
2200/*!
2201 Returns the item's tool tip, or an empty QString if no tool tip has been
2202 set.
2203
2204 \sa setToolTip(), QToolTip
2205*/
2206QString QGraphicsItem::toolTip() const
2207{
2208 return d_ptr->extra(type: QGraphicsItemPrivate::ExtraToolTip).toString();
2209}
2210
2211/*!
2212 Sets the item's tool tip to \a toolTip. If \a toolTip is empty, the item's
2213 tool tip is cleared.
2214
2215 \sa toolTip(), QToolTip
2216*/
2217void QGraphicsItem::setToolTip(const QString &toolTip)
2218{
2219 const QVariant toolTipVariant(itemChange(change: ItemToolTipChange, value: toolTip));
2220 d_ptr->setExtra(type: QGraphicsItemPrivate::ExtraToolTip, value: toolTipVariant.toString());
2221 itemChange(change: ItemToolTipHasChanged, value: toolTipVariant);
2222}
2223#endif // QT_CONFIG(tooltip)
2224
2225#ifndef QT_NO_CURSOR
2226/*!
2227 Returns the current cursor shape for the item. The mouse cursor
2228 will assume this shape when it's over this item.
2229 See the \l{Qt::CursorShape}{list of predefined cursor objects} for a
2230 range of useful shapes.
2231
2232 An editor item might want to use an I-beam cursor:
2233
2234 \snippet code/src_gui_graphicsview_qgraphicsitem.cpp 2
2235
2236 If no cursor has been set, the cursor of the item beneath is used.
2237
2238 \sa setCursor(), hasCursor(), unsetCursor(), QWidget::cursor,
2239 QGuiApplication::overrideCursor()
2240*/
2241QCursor QGraphicsItem::cursor() const
2242{
2243 return qvariant_cast<QCursor>(v: d_ptr->extra(type: QGraphicsItemPrivate::ExtraCursor));
2244}
2245
2246/*!
2247 Sets the current cursor shape for the item to \a cursor. The mouse cursor
2248 will assume this shape when it's over this item.
2249 See the \l{Qt::CursorShape}{list of predefined cursor objects} for a
2250 range of useful shapes.
2251
2252 An editor item might want to use an I-beam cursor:
2253
2254 \snippet code/src_gui_graphicsview_qgraphicsitem.cpp 3
2255
2256 If no cursor has been set, the cursor of the item beneath is used.
2257
2258 \sa cursor(), hasCursor(), unsetCursor(), QWidget::cursor,
2259 QGuiApplication::overrideCursor()
2260*/
2261void QGraphicsItem::setCursor(const QCursor &cursor)
2262{
2263 const QVariant cursorVariant(itemChange(change: ItemCursorChange, value: QVariant::fromValue<QCursor>(value: cursor)));
2264 d_ptr->setExtra(type: QGraphicsItemPrivate::ExtraCursor, value: qvariant_cast<QCursor>(v: cursorVariant));
2265 d_ptr->hasCursor = 1;
2266 if (d_ptr->scene) {
2267 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->allItemsUseDefaultCursor = false;
2268 const auto views = d_ptr->scene->views();
2269 for (QGraphicsView *view : views) {
2270 view->viewport()->setMouseTracking(true);
2271 // Note: Some of this logic is duplicated in QGraphicsView's mouse events.
2272 if (view->underMouse()) {
2273 const QPoint viewPoint = view->mapFromGlobal(QCursor::pos());
2274 const QPointF cursorPos = mapFromScene(point: view->mapToScene(point: viewPoint));
2275 // the cursor can only change if the current item is under the mouse
2276 if (boundingRect().contains(p: cursorPos)) {
2277 const auto itemsUnderCursor = view->items(pos: viewPoint);
2278 for (QGraphicsItem *itemUnderCursor : itemsUnderCursor) {
2279 if (itemUnderCursor->hasCursor()) {
2280 QMetaObject::invokeMethod(obj: view, member: "_q_setViewportCursor",
2281 Q_ARG(QCursor, itemUnderCursor->cursor()));
2282 break;
2283 }
2284 }
2285 }
2286 break;
2287 }
2288 }
2289 }
2290 itemChange(change: ItemCursorHasChanged, value: cursorVariant);
2291}
2292
2293/*!
2294 Returns \c true if this item has a cursor set; otherwise, false is returned.
2295
2296 By default, items don't have any cursor set. cursor() will return a
2297 standard pointing arrow cursor.
2298
2299 \sa unsetCursor()
2300*/
2301bool QGraphicsItem::hasCursor() const
2302{
2303 return d_ptr->hasCursor;
2304}
2305
2306/*!
2307 Clears the cursor from this item.
2308
2309 \sa hasCursor(), setCursor()
2310*/
2311void QGraphicsItem::unsetCursor()
2312{
2313 if (!d_ptr->hasCursor)
2314 return;
2315 d_ptr->unsetExtra(type: QGraphicsItemPrivate::ExtraCursor);
2316 d_ptr->hasCursor = 0;
2317 if (d_ptr->scene) {
2318 const auto views = d_ptr->scene->views();
2319 for (QGraphicsView *view : views) {
2320 if (view->underMouse() && view->itemAt(pos: view->mapFromGlobal(QCursor::pos())) == this) {
2321 QMetaObject::invokeMethod(obj: view, member: "_q_unsetViewportCursor");
2322 break;
2323 }
2324 }
2325 }
2326}
2327
2328#endif // QT_NO_CURSOR
2329
2330/*!
2331 Returns \c true if the item is visible; otherwise, false is returned.
2332
2333 Note that the item's general visibility is unrelated to whether or not it
2334 is actually being visualized by a QGraphicsView.
2335
2336 \sa setVisible()
2337*/
2338bool QGraphicsItem::isVisible() const
2339{
2340 return d_ptr->visible;
2341}
2342
2343/*!
2344 \since 4.4
2345 Returns \c true if the item is visible to \a parent; otherwise, false is
2346 returned. \a parent can be \nullptr, in which case this function will return
2347 whether the item is visible to the scene or not.
2348
2349 An item may not be visible to its ancestors even if isVisible() is true. It
2350 may also be visible to its ancestors even if isVisible() is false. If
2351 any ancestor is hidden, the item itself will be implicitly hidden, in which
2352 case this function will return false.
2353
2354 \sa isVisible(), setVisible()
2355*/
2356bool QGraphicsItem::isVisibleTo(const QGraphicsItem *parent) const
2357{
2358 const QGraphicsItem *p = this;
2359 if (d_ptr->explicitlyHidden)
2360 return false;
2361 do {
2362 if (p == parent)
2363 return true;
2364 if (p->d_ptr->explicitlyHidden)
2365 return false;
2366 } while ((p = p->d_ptr->parent));
2367 return parent == nullptr;
2368}
2369
2370/*!
2371 \internal
2372
2373 Sets this item's visibility to \a newVisible. If \a explicitly is true,
2374 this item will be "explicitly" \a newVisible; otherwise, it.. will not be.
2375*/
2376void QGraphicsItemPrivate::setVisibleHelper(bool newVisible, bool explicitly,
2377 bool update, bool hiddenByPanel)
2378{
2379 Q_Q(QGraphicsItem);
2380
2381 // Update explicit bit.
2382 if (explicitly)
2383 explicitlyHidden = newVisible ? 0 : 1;
2384
2385 // Check if there's nothing to do.
2386 if (visible == quint32(newVisible))
2387 return;
2388
2389 // Don't show child if parent is not visible
2390 if (parent && newVisible && !parent->d_ptr->visible)
2391 return;
2392
2393 // Modify the property.
2394 const QVariant newVisibleVariant(q_ptr->itemChange(change: QGraphicsItem::ItemVisibleChange,
2395 value: quint32(newVisible)));
2396 newVisible = newVisibleVariant.toBool();
2397 if (visible == quint32(newVisible))
2398 return;
2399 visible = newVisible;
2400
2401 // Schedule redrawing
2402 if (update) {
2403 QGraphicsItemCache *c = (QGraphicsItemCache *)qvariant_cast<void *>(v: extra(type: ExtraCacheData));
2404 if (c)
2405 c->purge();
2406 if (scene) {
2407#if QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
2408 invalidateParentGraphicsEffectsRecursively();
2409#endif // QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
2410 scene->d_func()->markDirty(item: q_ptr, rect: QRectF(), /*invalidateChildren=*/false, /*force=*/true);
2411 }
2412 }
2413
2414 // Certain properties are dropped as an item becomes invisible.
2415 bool hasFocus = q_ptr->hasFocus();
2416 if (!newVisible) {
2417 if (scene) {
2418 if (scene->d_func()->mouseGrabberItems.contains(t: q))
2419 q->ungrabMouse();
2420 if (scene->d_func()->keyboardGrabberItems.contains(t: q))
2421 q->ungrabKeyboard();
2422 if (q->isPanel() && panelModality != QGraphicsItem::NonModal)
2423 scene->d_func()->leaveModal(item: q_ptr);
2424 }
2425 if (hasFocus && scene) {
2426 // Hiding the focus item or the closest non-panel ancestor of the focus item
2427 QGraphicsItem *focusItem = scene->focusItem();
2428 bool clear = true;
2429 if (isWidget && !focusItem->isPanel()) {
2430 do {
2431 if (focusItem == q_ptr) {
2432 clear = !static_cast<QGraphicsWidget *>(q_ptr)->focusNextPrevChild(next: true);
2433 break;
2434 }
2435 } while ((focusItem = focusItem->parentWidget()) && !focusItem->isPanel());
2436 }
2437 if (clear)
2438 clearFocusHelper(/* giveFocusToParent = */ false, hiddenByParentPanel: hiddenByPanel);
2439 }
2440 if (q_ptr->isSelected())
2441 q_ptr->setSelected(false);
2442 } else {
2443 geometryChanged = 1;
2444 paintedViewBoundingRectsNeedRepaint = 1;
2445 if (scene) {
2446 if (isWidget) {
2447 QGraphicsWidget *widget = static_cast<QGraphicsWidget *>(q_ptr);
2448 if (widget->windowType() == Qt::Popup)
2449 scene->d_func()->addPopup(widget);
2450 }
2451 if (q->isPanel() && panelModality != QGraphicsItem::NonModal) {
2452 scene->d_func()->enterModal(item: q_ptr);
2453 }
2454 }
2455 }
2456
2457 // Update children with explicitly = false.
2458 const bool updateChildren = update && !((flags & QGraphicsItem::ItemClipsChildrenToShape
2459 || flags & QGraphicsItem::ItemContainsChildrenInShape)
2460 && !(flags & QGraphicsItem::ItemHasNoContents));
2461 for (QGraphicsItem *child : std::as_const(t&: children)) {
2462 if (!newVisible || !child->d_ptr->explicitlyHidden)
2463 child->d_ptr->setVisibleHelper(newVisible, explicitly: false, update: updateChildren, hiddenByPanel);
2464 }
2465
2466 // Update activation
2467 if (scene && q->isPanel()) {
2468 if (newVisible) {
2469 if (parent && parent->isActive())
2470 q->setActive(true);
2471 } else {
2472 if (q->isActive())
2473 scene->setActivePanel(parent);
2474 }
2475 }
2476
2477 // Enable subfocus
2478 if (scene) {
2479 if (newVisible) {
2480 // Item is shown
2481 QGraphicsItem *p = parent;
2482 bool done = false;
2483 while (p) {
2484 if (p->flags() & QGraphicsItem::ItemIsFocusScope) {
2485 QGraphicsItem *fsi = p->d_ptr->focusScopeItem;
2486 if (q_ptr == fsi || q_ptr->isAncestorOf(child: fsi)) {
2487 done = true;
2488 while (fsi->d_ptr->focusScopeItem && fsi->d_ptr->focusScopeItem->isVisible())
2489 fsi = fsi->d_ptr->focusScopeItem;
2490 fsi->d_ptr->setFocusHelper(focusReason: Qt::OtherFocusReason, /* climb = */ true,
2491 /* focusFromHide = */ false);
2492 }
2493 break;
2494 }
2495 p = p->d_ptr->parent;
2496 }
2497 if (!done) {
2498 QGraphicsItem *fi = subFocusItem;
2499 if (fi && fi != scene->focusItem()) {
2500 scene->setFocusItem(item: fi);
2501 } else if (flags & QGraphicsItem::ItemIsFocusScope &&
2502 !scene->focusItem() &&
2503 q->isAncestorOf(child: scene->d_func()->lastFocusItem)) {
2504 q_ptr->setFocus();
2505 }
2506 }
2507 } else {
2508 // Item is hidden
2509 if (hasFocus) {
2510 QGraphicsItem *p = parent;
2511 while (p) {
2512 if (p->flags() & QGraphicsItem::ItemIsFocusScope) {
2513 if (p->d_ptr->visible) {
2514 p->d_ptr->setFocusHelper(focusReason: Qt::OtherFocusReason, /* climb = */ true,
2515 /* focusFromHide = */ true);
2516 }
2517 break;
2518 }
2519 p = p->d_ptr->parent;
2520 }
2521 }
2522 }
2523 }
2524
2525 // Deliver post-change notification.
2526 q_ptr->itemChange(change: QGraphicsItem::ItemVisibleHasChanged, value: newVisibleVariant);
2527
2528 if (isObject)
2529 emit static_cast<QGraphicsObject *>(q_ptr)->visibleChanged();
2530}
2531
2532/*!
2533 If \a visible is true, the item is made visible. Otherwise, the item is
2534 made invisible. Invisible items are not painted, nor do they receive any
2535 events. In particular, mouse events pass right through invisible items,
2536 and are delivered to any item that may be behind. Invisible items are also
2537 unselectable, they cannot take input focus, and are not detected by
2538 QGraphicsScene's item location functions.
2539
2540 If an item becomes invisible while grabbing the mouse, (i.e., while it is
2541 receiving mouse events,) it will automatically lose the mouse grab, and
2542 the grab is not regained by making the item visible again; it must receive
2543 a new mouse press to regain the mouse grab.
2544
2545 Similarly, an invisible item cannot have focus, so if the item has focus
2546 when it becomes invisible, it will lose focus, and the focus is not
2547 regained by simply making the item visible again.
2548
2549 If you hide a parent item, all its children will also be hidden. If you
2550 show a parent item, all children will be shown, unless they have been
2551 explicitly hidden (i.e., if you call setVisible(false) on a child, it will
2552 not be reshown even if its parent is hidden, and then shown again).
2553
2554 Items are visible by default; it is unnecessary to call
2555 setVisible() on a new item.
2556
2557 \note An item with opacity set to 0 will still be considered visible,
2558 although it will be treated like an invisible item: mouse events will pass
2559 through it, it will not be included in the items returned by
2560 QGraphicsView::items(), and so on. However, the item will retain the focus.
2561
2562 \sa isVisible(), show(), hide(), setOpacity()
2563*/
2564void QGraphicsItem::setVisible(bool visible)
2565{
2566 d_ptr->setVisibleHelper(newVisible: visible,
2567 /* explicit = */ explicitly: true,
2568 /* update = */ true,
2569 /* hiddenByPanel = */ isPanel());
2570}
2571
2572/*!
2573 \fn void QGraphicsItem::hide()
2574
2575 Hides the item (items are visible by default).
2576
2577 This convenience function is equivalent to calling \c setVisible(false).
2578
2579 \sa show(), setVisible()
2580*/
2581
2582/*!
2583 \fn void QGraphicsItem::show()
2584
2585 Shows the item (items are visible by default).
2586
2587 This convenience function is equivalent to calling \c setVisible(true).
2588
2589 \sa hide(), setVisible()
2590*/
2591
2592/*!
2593 Returns \c true if the item is enabled; otherwise, false is returned.
2594
2595 \sa setEnabled()
2596*/
2597bool QGraphicsItem::isEnabled() const
2598{
2599 return d_ptr->enabled;
2600}
2601
2602/*!
2603 \internal
2604
2605 Sets this item's visibility to \a newEnabled. If \a explicitly is true,
2606 this item will be "explicitly" \a newEnabled; otherwise, it.. will not be.
2607*/
2608void QGraphicsItemPrivate::setEnabledHelper(bool newEnabled, bool explicitly, bool update)
2609{
2610 // Update explicit bit.
2611 if (explicitly)
2612 explicitlyDisabled = newEnabled ? 0 : 1;
2613
2614 // Check if there's nothing to do.
2615 if (enabled == quint32(newEnabled))
2616 return;
2617
2618 // Certain properties are dropped when an item is disabled.
2619 if (!newEnabled) {
2620 if (scene) {
2621 if (scene->mouseGrabberItem() == q_ptr)
2622 q_ptr->ungrabMouse();
2623 if (q_ptr->hasFocus()) {
2624 // Disabling the closest non-panel ancestor of the focus item
2625 // causes focus to pop to the next item, otherwise it's cleared.
2626 QGraphicsItem *focusItem = scene->focusItem();
2627 bool clear = true;
2628 if (isWidget && !focusItem->isPanel() && q_ptr->isAncestorOf(child: focusItem)) {
2629 do {
2630 if (focusItem == q_ptr) {
2631 clear = !static_cast<QGraphicsWidget *>(q_ptr)->focusNextPrevChild(next: true);
2632 break;
2633 }
2634 } while ((focusItem = focusItem->parentWidget()) && !focusItem->isPanel());
2635 }
2636 if (clear)
2637 q_ptr->clearFocus();
2638 }
2639 }
2640 if (q_ptr->isSelected())
2641 q_ptr->setSelected(false);
2642 }
2643
2644 // Modify the property.
2645 const QVariant newEnabledVariant(q_ptr->itemChange(change: QGraphicsItem::ItemEnabledChange,
2646 value: quint32(newEnabled)));
2647 enabled = newEnabledVariant.toBool();
2648
2649 // Schedule redraw.
2650 if (update)
2651 q_ptr->update();
2652
2653 for (QGraphicsItem *child : std::as_const(t&: children)) {
2654 if (!newEnabled || !child->d_ptr->explicitlyDisabled)
2655 child->d_ptr->setEnabledHelper(newEnabled, /* explicitly = */ false);
2656 }
2657
2658 // Deliver post-change notification.
2659 q_ptr->itemChange(change: QGraphicsItem::ItemEnabledHasChanged, value: newEnabledVariant);
2660
2661 if (isObject)
2662 emit static_cast<QGraphicsObject *>(q_ptr)->enabledChanged();
2663}
2664
2665/*!
2666 If \a enabled is true, the item is enabled; otherwise, it is disabled.
2667
2668 Disabled items are visible, but they do not receive any events, and cannot
2669 take focus nor be selected. Mouse events are discarded; they are not
2670 propagated unless the item is also invisible, or if it does not accept
2671 mouse events (see acceptedMouseButtons()). A disabled item cannot become the
2672 mouse grabber, and as a result of this, an item loses the grab if it
2673 becomes disabled when grabbing the mouse, just like it loses focus if it
2674 had focus when it was disabled.
2675
2676 Disabled items are traditionally drawn using grayed-out colors (see \l
2677 QPalette::Disabled).
2678
2679 If you disable a parent item, all its children will also be disabled. If
2680 you enable a parent item, all children will be enabled, unless they have
2681 been explicitly disabled (i.e., if you call setEnabled(false) on a child,
2682 it will not be re-enabled if its parent is disabled, and then enabled
2683 again).
2684
2685 Items are enabled by default.
2686
2687 \note If you install an event filter, you can still intercept events
2688 before they are delivered to items; this mechanism disregards the item's
2689 enabled state.
2690
2691 \sa isEnabled()
2692*/
2693void QGraphicsItem::setEnabled(bool enabled)
2694{
2695 d_ptr->setEnabledHelper(newEnabled: enabled, /* explicitly = */ true);
2696}
2697
2698/*!
2699 Returns \c true if this item is selected; otherwise, false is returned.
2700
2701 Items that are in a group inherit the group's selected state.
2702
2703 Items are not selected by default.
2704
2705 \sa setSelected(), QGraphicsScene::setSelectionArea()
2706*/
2707bool QGraphicsItem::isSelected() const
2708{
2709 if (QGraphicsItemGroup *group = this->group())
2710 return group->isSelected();
2711 return d_ptr->selected;
2712}
2713
2714/*!
2715 If \a selected is true and this item is selectable, this item is selected;
2716 otherwise, it is unselected.
2717
2718 If the item is in a group, the whole group's selected state is toggled by
2719 this function. If the group is selected, all items in the group are also
2720 selected, and if the group is not selected, no item in the group is
2721 selected.
2722
2723 Only visible, enabled, selectable items can be selected. If \a selected
2724 is true and this item is either invisible or disabled or unselectable,
2725 this function does nothing.
2726
2727 By default, items cannot be selected. To enable selection, set the
2728 ItemIsSelectable flag.
2729
2730 This function is provided for convenience, allowing individual toggling of
2731 the selected state of an item. However, a more common way of selecting
2732 items is to call QGraphicsScene::setSelectionArea(), which will call this
2733 function for all visible, enabled, and selectable items within a specified
2734 area on the scene.
2735
2736 \sa isSelected(), QGraphicsScene::selectedItems()
2737*/
2738void QGraphicsItem::setSelected(bool selected)
2739{
2740 if (QGraphicsItemGroup *group = this->group()) {
2741 group->setSelected(selected);
2742 return;
2743 }
2744
2745 if (!(d_ptr->flags & ItemIsSelectable) || !d_ptr->enabled || !d_ptr->visible)
2746 selected = false;
2747 if (d_ptr->selected == selected)
2748 return;
2749 const QVariant newSelectedVariant(itemChange(change: ItemSelectedChange, value: quint32(selected)));
2750 bool newSelected = newSelectedVariant.toBool();
2751 if (d_ptr->selected == newSelected)
2752 return;
2753 d_ptr->selected = newSelected;
2754
2755 update();
2756 if (d_ptr->scene) {
2757 QGraphicsScenePrivate *sceneD = d_ptr->scene->d_func();
2758 if (selected) {
2759 sceneD->selectedItems << this;
2760 } else {
2761 // QGraphicsScene::selectedItems() lazily pulls out all items that are
2762 // no longer selected.
2763 }
2764 if (!sceneD->selectionChanging)
2765 emit d_ptr->scene->selectionChanged();
2766 }
2767
2768 // Deliver post-change notification.
2769 itemChange(change: QGraphicsItem::ItemSelectedHasChanged, value: newSelectedVariant);
2770}
2771
2772/*!
2773 \since 4.5
2774
2775 Returns this item's local opacity, which is between 0.0 (transparent) and
2776 1.0 (opaque). This value is combined with parent and ancestor values into
2777 the effectiveOpacity(). The effective opacity decides how the item is
2778 rendered and also affects its visibility when queried by functions such as
2779 QGraphicsView::items().
2780
2781 The opacity property decides the state of the painter passed to the
2782 paint() function. If the item is cached, i.e., ItemCoordinateCache or
2783 DeviceCoordinateCache, the effective property will be applied to the item's
2784 cache as it is rendered.
2785
2786 The default opacity is 1.0; fully opaque.
2787
2788 \sa setOpacity(), paint(), ItemIgnoresParentOpacity,
2789 ItemDoesntPropagateOpacityToChildren
2790*/
2791qreal QGraphicsItem::opacity() const
2792{
2793 return d_ptr->opacity;
2794}
2795
2796/*!
2797 \since 4.5
2798
2799 Returns this item's \e effective opacity, which is between 0.0
2800 (transparent) and 1.0 (opaque). This value is a combination of this item's
2801 local opacity, and its parent and ancestors' opacities. The effective
2802 opacity decides how the item is rendered.
2803
2804 \sa opacity(), setOpacity(), paint(), ItemIgnoresParentOpacity,
2805 ItemDoesntPropagateOpacityToChildren
2806*/
2807qreal QGraphicsItem::effectiveOpacity() const
2808{
2809 return d_ptr->effectiveOpacity();
2810}
2811
2812/*!
2813 \since 4.5
2814
2815 Sets this item's local \a opacity, between 0.0 (transparent) and 1.0
2816 (opaque). The item's local opacity is combined with parent and ancestor
2817 opacities into the effectiveOpacity().
2818
2819 By default, opacity propagates from parent to child, so if a parent's
2820 opacity is 0.5 and the child is also 0.5, the child's effective opacity
2821 will be 0.25.
2822
2823 The opacity property decides the state of the painter passed to the
2824 paint() function. If the item is cached, i.e., ItemCoordinateCache or
2825 DeviceCoordinateCache, the effective property will be applied to the
2826 item's cache as it is rendered.
2827
2828 There are two item flags that affect how the item's opacity is combined
2829 with the parent: ItemIgnoresParentOpacity and
2830 ItemDoesntPropagateOpacityToChildren.
2831
2832 \note Setting the opacity of an item to 0 will not make the item invisible
2833 (according to isVisible()), but the item will be treated like an invisible
2834 one. See the documentation of setVisible() for more information.
2835
2836 \sa opacity(), effectiveOpacity(), setVisible()
2837*/
2838void QGraphicsItem::setOpacity(qreal opacity)
2839{
2840 // Notify change.
2841 const QVariant newOpacityVariant(itemChange(change: ItemOpacityChange, value: opacity));
2842
2843 // Normalized opacity
2844 qreal newOpacity = qBound(min: qreal(0), val: newOpacityVariant.toReal(), max: qreal(1));
2845
2846 // No change? Done.
2847 if (newOpacity == d_ptr->opacity)
2848 return;
2849
2850 bool wasFullyTransparent = d_ptr->isOpacityNull();
2851 d_ptr->opacity = newOpacity;
2852
2853 // Notify change.
2854 itemChange(change: ItemOpacityHasChanged, value: newOpacityVariant);
2855
2856 // Update.
2857 if (d_ptr->scene) {
2858#if QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
2859 d_ptr->invalidateParentGraphicsEffectsRecursively();
2860 if (!(d_ptr->flags & ItemDoesntPropagateOpacityToChildren))
2861 d_ptr->invalidateChildGraphicsEffectsRecursively(reason: QGraphicsItemPrivate::OpacityChanged);
2862#endif // QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
2863 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->markDirty(item: this, rect: QRectF(),
2864 /*invalidateChildren=*/true,
2865 /*force=*/false,
2866 /*ignoreOpacity=*/d_ptr->isOpacityNull());
2867 if (wasFullyTransparent)
2868 d_ptr->paintedViewBoundingRectsNeedRepaint = 1;
2869 }
2870
2871 if (d_ptr->isObject)
2872 emit static_cast<QGraphicsObject *>(this)->opacityChanged();
2873}
2874
2875/*!
2876 Returns a pointer to this item's effect if it has one; otherwise \nullptr.
2877
2878 \since 4.6
2879*/
2880#if QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
2881QGraphicsEffect *QGraphicsItem::graphicsEffect() const
2882{
2883 return d_ptr->graphicsEffect;
2884}
2885
2886/*!
2887 Sets \a effect as the item's effect. If there already is an effect installed
2888 on this item, QGraphicsItem will delete the existing effect before installing
2889 the new \a effect. You can delete an existing effect by calling
2890 setGraphicsEffect(\nullptr).
2891
2892 If \a effect is the installed effect on a different item, setGraphicsEffect() will remove
2893 the effect from the item and install it on this item.
2894
2895 QGraphicsItem takes ownership of \a effect.
2896
2897 \note This function will apply the effect on itself and all its children.
2898
2899 \since 4.6
2900*/
2901void QGraphicsItem::setGraphicsEffect(QGraphicsEffect *effect)
2902{
2903 if (d_ptr->graphicsEffect == effect)
2904 return;
2905
2906 if (d_ptr->graphicsEffect) {
2907 delete d_ptr->graphicsEffect;
2908 d_ptr->graphicsEffect = nullptr;
2909 } else if (d_ptr->parent) {
2910 d_ptr->parent->d_ptr->updateChildWithGraphicsEffectFlagRecursively();
2911 }
2912
2913 if (effect) {
2914 // Set new effect.
2915 QGraphicsEffectSourcePrivate *sourced = new QGraphicsItemEffectSourcePrivate(this);
2916 QGraphicsEffectSource *source = new QGraphicsEffectSource(*sourced);
2917 d_ptr->graphicsEffect = effect;
2918 effect->d_func()->setGraphicsEffectSource(source);
2919 prepareGeometryChange();
2920 }
2921}
2922#endif // QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
2923
2924void QGraphicsItemPrivate::updateChildWithGraphicsEffectFlagRecursively()
2925{
2926#if QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
2927 QGraphicsItemPrivate *itemPrivate = this;
2928 do {
2929 // parent chain already notified?
2930 if (itemPrivate->mayHaveChildWithGraphicsEffect)
2931 return;
2932 itemPrivate->mayHaveChildWithGraphicsEffect = 1;
2933 } while ((itemPrivate = itemPrivate->parent ? itemPrivate->parent->d_ptr.data() : nullptr));
2934#endif
2935}
2936
2937/*!
2938 \internal
2939 \since 4.6
2940 Returns the effective bounding rect of the given item space rect.
2941 If the item has no effect, the rect is returned unmodified.
2942 If the item has an effect, the effective rect can be extend beyond the
2943 item's bounding rect, depending on the effect.
2944
2945 \sa boundingRect()
2946*/
2947QRectF QGraphicsItemPrivate::effectiveBoundingRect(const QRectF &rect) const
2948{
2949#if QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
2950 Q_Q(const QGraphicsItem);
2951 QGraphicsEffect *effect = graphicsEffect;
2952 if (scene && effect && effect->isEnabled()) {
2953 if (scene->d_func()->views.isEmpty())
2954 return effect->boundingRectFor(sourceRect: rect);
2955 QRectF sceneRect = q->mapRectToScene(rect);
2956 QRectF sceneEffectRect;
2957 const auto views = scene->views();
2958 for (QGraphicsView *view : views) {
2959 QRectF deviceRect = view->d_func()->mapRectFromScene(rect: sceneRect);
2960 QRect deviceEffectRect = effect->boundingRectFor(sourceRect: deviceRect).toAlignedRect();
2961 sceneEffectRect |= view->d_func()->mapRectToScene(rect: deviceEffectRect);
2962 }
2963 return q->mapRectFromScene(rect: sceneEffectRect);
2964 }
2965#endif // QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
2966 return rect;
2967}
2968
2969/*!
2970 \internal
2971 \since 4.6
2972 Returns the effective bounding rect of the item.
2973 If the item has no effect, this is the same as the item's bounding rect.
2974 If the item has an effect, the effective rect can be larger than the item's
2975 bounding rect, depending on the effect.
2976
2977 \sa boundingRect()
2978*/
2979QRectF QGraphicsItemPrivate::effectiveBoundingRect(QGraphicsItem *topMostEffectItem) const
2980{
2981#if QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
2982 Q_Q(const QGraphicsItem);
2983 QRectF brect = effectiveBoundingRect(rect: q_ptr->boundingRect());
2984 if (ancestorFlags & QGraphicsItemPrivate::AncestorClipsChildren
2985 || ancestorFlags & QGraphicsItemPrivate::AncestorContainsChildren
2986 || topMostEffectItem == q)
2987 return brect;
2988
2989 const QGraphicsItem *effectParent = parent;
2990 while (effectParent) {
2991 QGraphicsEffect *effect = effectParent->d_ptr->graphicsEffect;
2992 if (scene && effect && effect->isEnabled()) {
2993 const QRectF brectInParentSpace = q->mapRectToItem(item: effectParent, rect: brect);
2994 const QRectF effectRectInParentSpace = effectParent->d_ptr->effectiveBoundingRect(rect: brectInParentSpace);
2995 brect = effectParent->mapRectToItem(item: q, rect: effectRectInParentSpace);
2996 }
2997 if (effectParent->d_ptr->ancestorFlags & QGraphicsItemPrivate::AncestorClipsChildren
2998 || effectParent->d_ptr->ancestorFlags & QGraphicsItemPrivate::AncestorContainsChildren
2999 || topMostEffectItem == effectParent) {
3000 return brect;
3001 }
3002 effectParent = effectParent->d_ptr->parent;
3003 }
3004
3005 return brect;
3006#else //QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
3007 Q_UNUSED(topMostEffectItem);
3008 return q_ptr->boundingRect();
3009#endif // QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
3010
3011}
3012
3013/*!
3014 \internal
3015 \since 4.6
3016 Returns the effective bounding rect of this item in scene coordinates,
3017 by combining sceneTransform() with boundingRect(), taking into account
3018 the effect that the item might have.
3019
3020 If the item has no effect, this is the same as sceneBoundingRect().
3021
3022 \sa effectiveBoundingRect(), sceneBoundingRect()
3023*/
3024QRectF QGraphicsItemPrivate::sceneEffectiveBoundingRect() const
3025{
3026 // Find translate-only offset
3027 // COMBINE
3028 QPointF offset;
3029 const QGraphicsItem *parentItem = q_ptr;
3030 const QGraphicsItemPrivate *itemd;
3031 do {
3032 itemd = parentItem->d_ptr.data();
3033 if (itemd->transformData)
3034 break;
3035 offset += itemd->pos;
3036 } while ((parentItem = itemd->parent));
3037
3038 QRectF br = effectiveBoundingRect();
3039 br.translate(p: offset);
3040 return !parentItem ? br : parentItem->sceneTransform().mapRect(br);
3041}
3042
3043/*!
3044 Returns \c true if this item can accept drag and drop events; otherwise,
3045 returns \c false. By default, items do not accept drag and drop events; items
3046 are transparent to drag and drop.
3047
3048 \sa setAcceptDrops()
3049*/
3050bool QGraphicsItem::acceptDrops() const
3051{
3052 return d_ptr->acceptDrops;
3053}
3054
3055/*!
3056 If \a on is true, this item will accept drag and drop events; otherwise,
3057 it is transparent for drag and drop events. By default, items do not
3058 accept drag and drop events.
3059
3060 \sa acceptDrops()
3061*/
3062void QGraphicsItem::setAcceptDrops(bool on)
3063{
3064 d_ptr->acceptDrops = on;
3065}
3066
3067/*!
3068 Returns the mouse buttons that this item accepts mouse events for. By
3069 default, all mouse buttons are accepted.
3070
3071 If an item accepts a mouse button, it will become the mouse
3072 grabber item when a mouse press event is delivered for that mouse
3073 button. However, if the item does not accept the button,
3074 QGraphicsScene will forward the mouse events to the first item
3075 beneath it that does.
3076
3077 \sa setAcceptedMouseButtons(), mousePressEvent()
3078*/
3079Qt::MouseButtons QGraphicsItem::acceptedMouseButtons() const
3080{
3081 return Qt::MouseButtons(d_ptr->acceptedMouseButtons);
3082}
3083
3084/*!
3085 Sets the mouse \a buttons that this item accepts mouse events for.
3086
3087 By default, all mouse buttons are accepted. If an item accepts a
3088 mouse button, it will become the mouse grabber item when a mouse
3089 press event is delivered for that button. However, if the item
3090 does not accept the mouse button, QGraphicsScene will forward the
3091 mouse events to the first item beneath it that does.
3092
3093 To disable mouse events for an item (i.e., make it transparent for mouse
3094 events), call setAcceptedMouseButtons(Qt::NoButton).
3095
3096 \sa acceptedMouseButtons(), mousePressEvent()
3097*/
3098void QGraphicsItem::setAcceptedMouseButtons(Qt::MouseButtons buttons)
3099{
3100 if (Qt::MouseButtons(d_ptr->acceptedMouseButtons) != buttons) {
3101 if (buttons == 0 && d_ptr->scene && d_ptr->scene->mouseGrabberItem() == this
3102 && d_ptr->scene->d_func()->lastMouseGrabberItemHasImplicitMouseGrab) {
3103 ungrabMouse();
3104 }
3105 d_ptr->acceptedMouseButtons = quint32(buttons);
3106 }
3107}
3108
3109/*!
3110 \since 4.4
3111
3112 Returns \c true if an item accepts hover events
3113 (QGraphicsSceneHoverEvent); otherwise, returns \c false. By default,
3114 items do not accept hover events.
3115
3116 \sa setAcceptedMouseButtons()
3117*/
3118bool QGraphicsItem::acceptHoverEvents() const
3119{
3120 return d_ptr->acceptsHover;
3121}
3122
3123
3124/*!
3125 \since 4.4
3126
3127 If \a enabled is true, this item will accept hover events;
3128 otherwise, it will ignore them. By default, items do not accept
3129 hover events.
3130
3131 Hover events are delivered when there is no current mouse grabber
3132 item. They are sent when the mouse cursor enters an item, when it
3133 moves around inside the item, and when the cursor leaves an
3134 item. Hover events are commonly used to highlight an item when
3135 it's entered, and for tracking the mouse cursor as it hovers over
3136 the item (equivalent to QWidget::mouseTracking).
3137
3138 Parent items receive hover enter events before their children, and
3139 leave events after their children. The parent does not receive a
3140 hover leave event if the cursor enters a child, though; the parent
3141 stays "hovered" until the cursor leaves its area, including its
3142 children's areas.
3143
3144 If a parent item handles child events, it will receive hover move,
3145 drag move, and drop events as the cursor passes through its
3146 children, but it does not receive hover enter and hover leave, nor
3147 drag enter and drag leave events on behalf of its children.
3148
3149 A QGraphicsWidget with window decorations will accept hover events
3150 regardless of the value of acceptHoverEvents().
3151
3152 \sa acceptHoverEvents(), hoverEnterEvent(), hoverMoveEvent(),
3153 hoverLeaveEvent()
3154*/
3155void QGraphicsItem::setAcceptHoverEvents(bool enabled)
3156{
3157 if (d_ptr->acceptsHover == quint32(enabled))
3158 return;
3159 d_ptr->acceptsHover = quint32(enabled);
3160 if (d_ptr->acceptsHover && d_ptr->scene && d_ptr->scene->d_func()->allItemsIgnoreHoverEvents) {
3161 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->allItemsIgnoreHoverEvents = false;
3162 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->enableMouseTrackingOnViews();
3163 }
3164}
3165
3166/*! \since 4.6
3167
3168 Returns \c true if an item accepts \l{QTouchEvent}{touch events};
3169 otherwise, returns \c false. By default, items do not accept touch events.
3170
3171 \sa setAcceptTouchEvents()
3172*/
3173bool QGraphicsItem::acceptTouchEvents() const
3174{
3175 return d_ptr->acceptTouchEvents;
3176}
3177
3178/*!
3179 \since 4.6
3180
3181 If \a enabled is true, this item will accept \l{QTouchEvent}{touch events};
3182 otherwise, it will ignore them. By default, items do not accept
3183 touch events.
3184*/
3185void QGraphicsItem::setAcceptTouchEvents(bool enabled)
3186{
3187 if (d_ptr->acceptTouchEvents == quint32(enabled))
3188 return;
3189 d_ptr->acceptTouchEvents = quint32(enabled);
3190 if (d_ptr->acceptTouchEvents && d_ptr->scene && d_ptr->scene->d_func()->allItemsIgnoreTouchEvents) {
3191 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->allItemsIgnoreTouchEvents = false;
3192 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->enableTouchEventsOnViews();
3193 }
3194}
3195
3196/*!
3197 \since 4.6
3198
3199 Returns \c true if this item filters child events (i.e., all events
3200 intended for any of its children are instead sent to this item);
3201 otherwise, false is returned.
3202
3203 The default value is false; child events are not filtered.
3204
3205 \sa setFiltersChildEvents()
3206*/
3207bool QGraphicsItem::filtersChildEvents() const
3208{
3209 return d_ptr->filtersDescendantEvents;
3210}
3211
3212/*!
3213 \since 4.6
3214
3215 If \a enabled is true, this item is set to filter all events for
3216 all its children (i.e., all events intended for any of its
3217 children are instead sent to this item); otherwise, if \a enabled
3218 is false, this item will only handle its own events. The default
3219 value is false.
3220
3221 \sa filtersChildEvents()
3222*/
3223void QGraphicsItem::setFiltersChildEvents(bool enabled)
3224{
3225 if (d_ptr->filtersDescendantEvents == enabled)
3226 return;
3227
3228 d_ptr->filtersDescendantEvents = enabled;
3229 d_ptr->updateAncestorFlag(childFlag: QGraphicsItem::GraphicsItemFlag(-2));
3230}
3231
3232/*!
3233 \deprecated
3234
3235 Returns \c true if this item handles child events (i.e., all events
3236 intended for any of its children are instead sent to this item);
3237 otherwise, false is returned.
3238
3239 This property is useful for item groups; it allows one item to
3240 handle events on behalf of its children, as opposed to its
3241 children handling their events individually.
3242
3243 The default is to return false; children handle their own events.
3244 The exception for this is if the item is a QGraphicsItemGroup, then
3245 it defaults to return true.
3246
3247 \sa setHandlesChildEvents()
3248*/
3249bool QGraphicsItem::handlesChildEvents() const
3250{
3251 return d_ptr->handlesChildEvents;
3252}
3253
3254/*!
3255 \deprecated
3256
3257 If \a enabled is true, this item is set to handle all events for
3258 all its children (i.e., all events intended for any of its
3259 children are instead sent to this item); otherwise, if \a enabled
3260 is false, this item will only handle its own events. The default
3261 value is false.
3262
3263 This property is useful for item groups; it allows one item to
3264 handle events on behalf of its children, as opposed to its
3265 children handling their events individually.
3266
3267 If a child item accepts hover events, its parent will receive
3268 hover move events as the cursor passes through the child, but it
3269 does not receive hover enter and hover leave events on behalf of
3270 its child.
3271
3272 \sa handlesChildEvents()
3273*/
3274void QGraphicsItem::setHandlesChildEvents(bool enabled)
3275{
3276 if (d_ptr->handlesChildEvents == enabled)
3277 return;
3278
3279 d_ptr->handlesChildEvents = enabled;
3280 d_ptr->updateAncestorFlag(childFlag: QGraphicsItem::GraphicsItemFlag(-1));
3281}
3282/*!
3283 \since 4.6
3284 Returns \c true if this item is active; otherwise returns \c false.
3285
3286 An item can only be active if the scene is active. An item is active
3287 if it is, or is a descendent of, an active panel. Items in non-active
3288 panels are not active.
3289
3290 Items that are not part of a panel follow scene activation when the
3291 scene has no active panel.
3292
3293 Only active items can gain input focus.
3294
3295 \sa QGraphicsScene::isActive(), QGraphicsScene::activePanel(), panel(), isPanel()
3296*/
3297bool QGraphicsItem::isActive() const
3298{
3299 if (!d_ptr->scene || !d_ptr->scene->isActive())
3300 return false;
3301 return panel() == d_ptr->scene->activePanel();
3302}
3303
3304/*!
3305 \since 4.6
3306
3307 If \a active is true, and the scene is active, this item's panel will be
3308 activated. Otherwise, the panel is deactivated.
3309
3310 If the item is not part of an active scene, \a active will decide what
3311 happens to the panel when the scene becomes active or the item is added to
3312 the scene. If true, the item's panel will be activated when the item is
3313 either added to the scene or the scene is activated. Otherwise, the item
3314 will stay inactive independent of the scene's activated state.
3315
3316 \sa isPanel(), QGraphicsScene::setActivePanel(), QGraphicsScene::isActive()
3317*/
3318void QGraphicsItem::setActive(bool active)
3319{
3320 d_ptr->explicitActivate = 1;
3321 d_ptr->wantsActive = active;
3322 if (d_ptr->scene) {
3323 if (active) {
3324 // Activate this item.
3325 d_ptr->scene->setActivePanel(this);
3326 } else {
3327 QGraphicsItem *activePanel = d_ptr->scene->activePanel();
3328 QGraphicsItem *thisPanel = panel();
3329 if (!activePanel || activePanel == thisPanel) {
3330 // Deactivate this item, and reactivate the parent panel,
3331 // or the last active panel (if any).
3332 QGraphicsItem *nextToActivate = nullptr;
3333 if (d_ptr->parent)
3334 nextToActivate = d_ptr->parent->panel();
3335 if (!nextToActivate)
3336 nextToActivate = d_ptr->scene->d_func()->lastActivePanel;
3337 if (nextToActivate == this || isAncestorOf(child: nextToActivate))
3338 nextToActivate = nullptr;
3339 d_ptr->scene->setActivePanel(nextToActivate);
3340 }
3341 }
3342 }
3343}
3344
3345/*!
3346 Returns \c true if this item is active, and it or its \l{focusProxy()}{focus
3347 proxy} has keyboard input focus; otherwise, returns \c false.
3348
3349 \sa focusItem(), setFocus(), QGraphicsScene::setFocusItem(), isActive()
3350*/
3351bool QGraphicsItem::hasFocus() const
3352{
3353 if (!d_ptr->scene || !d_ptr->scene->isActive())
3354 return false;
3355
3356 if (d_ptr->focusProxy)
3357 return d_ptr->focusProxy->hasFocus();
3358
3359 if (d_ptr->scene->d_func()->focusItem != this)
3360 return false;
3361
3362 return panel() == d_ptr->scene->d_func()->activePanel;
3363}
3364
3365/*!
3366 Gives keyboard input focus to this item. The \a focusReason argument will
3367 be passed into any \l{QFocusEvent}{focus event} generated by this function;
3368 it is used to give an explanation of what caused the item to get focus.
3369
3370 Only enabled items that set the ItemIsFocusable flag can accept keyboard
3371 focus.
3372
3373 If this item is not visible, not active, or not associated with a scene,
3374 it will not gain immediate input focus. However, it will be registered as
3375 the preferred focus item for its subtree of items, should it later become
3376 visible.
3377
3378 As a result of calling this function, this item will receive a
3379 \l{focusInEvent()}{focus in event} with \a focusReason. If another item
3380 already has focus, that item will first receive a \l{focusOutEvent()}
3381 {focus out event} indicating that it has lost input focus.
3382
3383 \sa clearFocus(), hasFocus(), focusItem(), focusProxy()
3384*/
3385void QGraphicsItem::setFocus(Qt::FocusReason focusReason)
3386{
3387 d_ptr->setFocusHelper(focusReason, /* climb = */ true, /* focusFromHide = */ false);
3388}
3389
3390/*!
3391 \internal
3392*/
3393void QGraphicsItemPrivate::setFocusHelper(Qt::FocusReason focusReason, bool climb, bool focusFromHide)
3394{
3395 // Disabled / unfocusable items cannot accept focus.
3396 if (!q_ptr->isEnabled() || !(flags & QGraphicsItem::ItemIsFocusable))
3397 return;
3398
3399 // Find focus proxy.
3400 QGraphicsItem *f = q_ptr;
3401 while (f->d_ptr->focusProxy)
3402 f = f->d_ptr->focusProxy;
3403
3404 // Return if it already has focus.
3405 if (scene && scene->focusItem() == f)
3406 return;
3407
3408 // Update focus scope item ptr.
3409 QGraphicsItem *p = parent;
3410 while (p) {
3411 if (p->flags() & QGraphicsItem::ItemIsFocusScope) {
3412 QGraphicsItem *oldFocusScopeItem = p->d_ptr->focusScopeItem;
3413 p->d_ptr->focusScopeItem = q_ptr;
3414 if (oldFocusScopeItem)
3415 oldFocusScopeItem->d_ptr->focusScopeItemChange(isSubFocusItem: false);
3416 focusScopeItemChange(isSubFocusItem: true);
3417 if (!p->focusItem() && !focusFromHide) {
3418 // Calling setFocus() on a child of a focus scope that does
3419 // not have focus changes only the focus scope pointer,
3420 // so that focus is restored the next time the scope gains
3421 // focus.
3422 return;
3423 }
3424 break;
3425 }
3426 p = p->d_ptr->parent;
3427 }
3428
3429 if (climb) {
3430 while (f->d_ptr->focusScopeItem && f->d_ptr->focusScopeItem->isVisible())
3431 f = f->d_ptr->focusScopeItem;
3432 }
3433
3434 // Update the child focus chain.
3435 QGraphicsItem *commonAncestor = nullptr;
3436 if (scene && scene->focusItem() && scene->focusItem()->panel() == q_ptr->panel()) {
3437 commonAncestor = scene->focusItem()->commonAncestorItem(other: f);
3438 scene->focusItem()->d_ptr->clearSubFocus(rootItem: scene->focusItem(), stopItem: commonAncestor);
3439 }
3440
3441 f->d_ptr->setSubFocus(rootItem: f, stopItem: commonAncestor);
3442
3443 // Update the scene's focus item.
3444 if (scene) {
3445 QGraphicsItem *p = q_ptr->panel();
3446 if ((!p && scene->isActive()) || (p && p->isActive())) {
3447 // Visible items immediately gain focus from scene.
3448 scene->d_func()->setFocusItemHelper(item: f, focusReason);
3449 }
3450 }
3451}
3452
3453/*!
3454 Takes keyboard input focus from the item.
3455
3456 If it has focus, a \l{focusOutEvent()}{focus out event} is sent to this
3457 item to tell it that it is about to lose the focus.
3458
3459 Only items that set the ItemIsFocusable flag, or widgets that set an
3460 appropriate focus policy, can accept keyboard focus.
3461
3462 \sa setFocus(), hasFocus(), QGraphicsWidget::focusPolicy
3463*/
3464void QGraphicsItem::clearFocus()
3465{
3466 d_ptr->clearFocusHelper(/* giveFocusToParent = */ true,
3467 /* hiddenByParentPanel = */ false);
3468}
3469
3470/*!
3471 \internal
3472*/
3473void QGraphicsItemPrivate::clearFocusHelper(bool giveFocusToParent, bool hiddenByParentPanel)
3474{
3475 QGraphicsItem *subFocusItem = q_ptr;
3476 if (flags & QGraphicsItem::ItemIsFocusScope) {
3477 while (subFocusItem->d_ptr->focusScopeItem)
3478 subFocusItem = subFocusItem->d_ptr->focusScopeItem;
3479 }
3480
3481 if (giveFocusToParent) {
3482 // Pass focus to the closest parent focus scope
3483 if (!inDestructor) {
3484 QGraphicsItem *p = parent;
3485 while (p) {
3486 if (p->flags() & QGraphicsItem::ItemIsFocusScope) {
3487 if (p->d_ptr->focusScopeItem == q_ptr) {
3488 p->d_ptr->focusScopeItem = nullptr;
3489 if (!subFocusItem->hasFocus()) //if it has focus, focusScopeItemChange is called elsewhere
3490 focusScopeItemChange(isSubFocusItem: false);
3491 }
3492 if (subFocusItem->hasFocus())
3493 p->d_ptr->setFocusHelper(focusReason: Qt::OtherFocusReason, /* climb = */ false,
3494 /* focusFromHide = */ false);
3495 return;
3496 }
3497 p = p->d_ptr->parent;
3498 }
3499 }
3500 }
3501
3502 if (subFocusItem->hasFocus()) {
3503 // Invisible items with focus must explicitly clear subfocus.
3504 if (!hiddenByParentPanel)
3505 clearSubFocus(rootItem: q_ptr);
3506
3507 // If this item has the scene's input focus, clear it.
3508 scene->setFocusItem(item: nullptr);
3509 }
3510}
3511
3512/*!
3513 \since 4.6
3514
3515 Returns this item's focus proxy, or \nullptr if this item has no
3516 focus proxy.
3517
3518 \sa setFocusProxy(), setFocus(), hasFocus()
3519*/
3520QGraphicsItem *QGraphicsItem::focusProxy() const
3521{
3522 return d_ptr->focusProxy;
3523}
3524
3525/*!
3526 \since 4.6
3527
3528 Sets the item's focus proxy to \a item.
3529
3530 If an item has a focus proxy, the focus proxy will receive
3531 input focus when the item gains input focus. The item itself
3532 will still have focus (i.e., hasFocus() will return true),
3533 but only the focus proxy will receive the keyboard input.
3534
3535 A focus proxy can itself have a focus proxy, and so on. In
3536 such case, keyboard input will be handled by the outermost
3537 focus proxy.
3538
3539 The focus proxy \a item must belong to the same scene as
3540 this item.
3541
3542 \sa focusProxy(), setFocus(), hasFocus()
3543*/
3544void QGraphicsItem::setFocusProxy(QGraphicsItem *item)
3545{
3546 if (item == d_ptr->focusProxy)
3547 return;
3548 if (item == this) {
3549 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::setFocusProxy: cannot assign self as focus proxy");
3550 return;
3551 }
3552 if (item) {
3553 if (item->d_ptr->scene != d_ptr->scene) {
3554 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::setFocusProxy: focus proxy must be in same scene");
3555 return;
3556 }
3557 for (QGraphicsItem *f = item->focusProxy(); f != nullptr; f = f->focusProxy()) {
3558 if (f == this) {
3559 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::setFocusProxy: %p is already in the focus proxy chain", item);
3560 return;
3561 }
3562 }
3563 }
3564
3565 QGraphicsItem *lastFocusProxy = d_ptr->focusProxy;
3566 if (lastFocusProxy)
3567 lastFocusProxy->d_ptr->focusProxyRefs.removeOne(t: &d_ptr->focusProxy);
3568 d_ptr->focusProxy = item;
3569 if (item)
3570 item->d_ptr->focusProxyRefs << &d_ptr->focusProxy;
3571}
3572
3573/*!
3574 \since 4.6
3575
3576 If this item, a child or descendant of this item currently has input
3577 focus, this function will return a pointer to that item. If
3578 no descendant has input focus, \nullptr is returned.
3579
3580 \sa hasFocus(), setFocus(), QWidget::focusWidget()
3581*/
3582QGraphicsItem *QGraphicsItem::focusItem() const
3583{
3584 return d_ptr->subFocusItem;
3585}
3586
3587/*!
3588 \internal
3589
3590 Returns this item's focus scope item.
3591*/
3592QGraphicsItem *QGraphicsItem::focusScopeItem() const
3593{
3594 return d_ptr->focusScopeItem;
3595}
3596
3597/*!
3598 \since 4.4
3599 Grabs the mouse input.
3600
3601 This item will receive all mouse events for the scene until any of the
3602 following events occurs:
3603
3604 \list
3605 \li The item becomes invisible
3606 \li The item is removed from the scene
3607 \li The item is deleted
3608 \li The item call ungrabMouse()
3609 \li Another item calls grabMouse(); the item will regain the mouse grab
3610 when the other item calls ungrabMouse().
3611 \endlist
3612
3613 When an item gains the mouse grab, it receives a QEvent::GrabMouse
3614 event. When it loses the mouse grab, it receives a QEvent::UngrabMouse
3615 event. These events can be used to detect when your item gains or loses
3616 the mouse grab through other means than receiving mouse button events.
3617
3618 It is almost never necessary to explicitly grab the mouse in Qt, as Qt
3619 grabs and releases it sensibly. In particular, Qt grabs the mouse when you
3620 press a mouse button, and keeps the mouse grabbed until you release the
3621 last mouse button. Also, Qt::Popup widgets implicitly call grabMouse()
3622 when shown, and ungrabMouse() when hidden.
3623
3624 Note that only visible items can grab mouse input. Calling grabMouse() on
3625 an invisible item has no effect.
3626
3627 Keyboard events are not affected.
3628
3629 \sa QGraphicsScene::mouseGrabberItem(), ungrabMouse(), grabKeyboard()
3630*/
3631void QGraphicsItem::grabMouse()
3632{
3633 if (!d_ptr->scene) {
3634 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::grabMouse: cannot grab mouse without scene");
3635 return;
3636 }
3637 if (!d_ptr->visible) {
3638 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::grabMouse: cannot grab mouse while invisible");
3639 return;
3640 }
3641 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->grabMouse(item: this);
3642}
3643
3644/*!
3645 \since 4.4
3646 Releases the mouse grab.
3647
3648 \sa grabMouse(), ungrabKeyboard()
3649*/
3650void QGraphicsItem::ungrabMouse()
3651{
3652 if (!d_ptr->scene) {
3653 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::ungrabMouse: cannot ungrab mouse without scene");
3654 return;
3655 }
3656 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->ungrabMouse(item: this);
3657}
3658
3659/*!
3660 \since 4.4
3661 Grabs the keyboard input.
3662
3663 The item will receive all keyboard input to the scene until one of the
3664 following events occur:
3665
3666 \list
3667 \li The item becomes invisible
3668 \li The item is removed from the scene
3669 \li The item is deleted
3670 \li The item calls ungrabKeyboard()
3671 \li Another item calls grabKeyboard(); the item will regain the keyboard grab
3672 when the other item calls ungrabKeyboard().
3673 \endlist
3674
3675 When an item gains the keyboard grab, it receives a QEvent::GrabKeyboard
3676 event. When it loses the keyboard grab, it receives a
3677 QEvent::UngrabKeyboard event. These events can be used to detect when your
3678 item gains or loses the keyboard grab through other means than gaining
3679 input focus.
3680
3681 It is almost never necessary to explicitly grab the keyboard in Qt, as Qt
3682 grabs and releases it sensibly. In particular, Qt grabs the keyboard when
3683 your item gains input focus, and releases it when your item loses input
3684 focus, or when the item is hidden.
3685
3686 Note that only visible items can grab keyboard input. Calling
3687 grabKeyboard() on an invisible item has no effect.
3688
3689 Keyboard events are not affected.
3690
3691 \sa ungrabKeyboard(), grabMouse(), setFocus()
3692*/
3693void QGraphicsItem::grabKeyboard()
3694{
3695 if (!d_ptr->scene) {
3696 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::grabKeyboard: cannot grab keyboard without scene");
3697 return;
3698 }
3699 if (!d_ptr->visible) {
3700 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::grabKeyboard: cannot grab keyboard while invisible");
3701 return;
3702 }
3703 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->grabKeyboard(item: this);
3704}
3705
3706/*!
3707 \since 4.4
3708 Releases the keyboard grab.
3709
3710 \sa grabKeyboard(), ungrabMouse()
3711*/
3712void QGraphicsItem::ungrabKeyboard()
3713{
3714 if (!d_ptr->scene) {
3715 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::ungrabKeyboard: cannot ungrab keyboard without scene");
3716 return;
3717 }
3718 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->ungrabKeyboard(item: this);
3719}
3720
3721/*!
3722 Returns the position of the item in parent coordinates. If the item has no
3723 parent, its position is given in scene coordinates.
3724
3725 The position of the item describes its origin (local coordinate
3726 (0, 0)) in parent coordinates; this function returns the same as
3727 mapToParent(0, 0).
3728
3729 For convenience, you can also call scenePos() to determine the
3730 item's position in scene coordinates, regardless of its parent.
3731
3732 \sa x(), y(), setPos(), transform(), {The Graphics View Coordinate System}
3733*/
3734QPointF QGraphicsItem::pos() const
3735{
3736 return d_ptr->pos;
3737}
3738
3739/*!
3740 \fn QGraphicsItem::x() const
3741
3742 This convenience function is equivalent to calling pos().x().
3743
3744 \sa y()
3745*/
3746
3747/*!
3748 \since 4.6
3749
3750 Set's the \a x coordinate of the item's position. Equivalent to
3751 calling setPos(x, y()).
3752
3753 \sa x(), setPos()
3754*/
3755void QGraphicsItem::setX(qreal x)
3756{
3757 if (d_ptr->inDestructor)
3758 return;
3759
3760 if (qIsNaN(d: x))
3761 return;
3762
3763 setPos(QPointF(x, d_ptr->pos.y()));
3764}
3765
3766/*!
3767 \fn QGraphicsItem::y() const
3768
3769 This convenience function is equivalent to calling pos().y().
3770
3771 \sa x()
3772*/
3773
3774/*!
3775 \since 4.6
3776
3777 Set's the \a y coordinate of the item's position. Equivalent to
3778 calling setPos(x(), y).
3779
3780 \sa x(), setPos()
3781*/
3782void QGraphicsItem::setY(qreal y)
3783{
3784 if (d_ptr->inDestructor)
3785 return;
3786
3787 if (qIsNaN(d: y))
3788 return;
3789
3790 setPos(QPointF(d_ptr->pos.x(), y));
3791}
3792
3793/*!
3794 Returns the item's position in scene coordinates. This is
3795 equivalent to calling \c mapToScene(0, 0).
3796
3797 \sa pos(), sceneTransform(), {The Graphics View Coordinate System}
3798*/
3799QPointF QGraphicsItem::scenePos() const
3800{
3801 return mapToScene(ax: 0, ay: 0);
3802}
3803
3804/*!
3805 \internal
3806
3807 Sets the position \a pos.
3808*/
3809void QGraphicsItemPrivate::setPosHelper(const QPointF &pos)
3810{
3811 Q_Q(QGraphicsItem);
3812 inSetPosHelper = 1;
3813 if (scene)
3814 q->prepareGeometryChange();
3815 QPointF oldPos = this->pos;
3816 this->pos = pos;
3817 dirtySceneTransform = 1;
3818 inSetPosHelper = 0;
3819 if (isObject) {
3820 if (pos.x() != oldPos.x())
3821 emit static_cast<QGraphicsObject *>(q_ptr)->xChanged();
3822 if (pos.y() != oldPos.y())
3823 emit static_cast<QGraphicsObject *>(q_ptr)->yChanged();
3824 }
3825}
3826
3827/*!
3828 \internal
3829
3830 Sets the transform \a transform.
3831*/
3832void QGraphicsItemPrivate::setTransformHelper(const QTransform &transform)
3833{
3834 q_ptr->prepareGeometryChange();
3835 transformData->transform = transform;
3836 dirtySceneTransform = 1;
3837 transformChanged();
3838}
3839
3840/*!
3841 Sets the position of the item to \a pos, which is in parent
3842 coordinates. For items with no parent, \a pos is in scene
3843 coordinates.
3844
3845 The position of the item describes its origin (local coordinate
3846 (0, 0)) in parent coordinates.
3847
3848 \sa pos(), scenePos(), {The Graphics View Coordinate System}
3849*/
3850void QGraphicsItem::setPos(const QPointF &pos)
3851{
3852 if (d_ptr->pos == pos)
3853 return;
3854
3855 if (d_ptr->inDestructor)
3856 return;
3857
3858 // Update and repositition.
3859 if (!(d_ptr->flags & (ItemSendsGeometryChanges | ItemSendsScenePositionChanges))) {
3860 d_ptr->setPosHelper(pos);
3861 if (d_ptr->isWidget)
3862 static_cast<QGraphicsWidget *>(this)->d_func()->setGeometryFromSetPos();
3863 if (d_ptr->scenePosDescendants)
3864 d_ptr->sendScenePosChange();
3865 return;
3866 }
3867
3868 // Notify the item that the position is changing.
3869 const QVariant newPosVariant(itemChange(change: ItemPositionChange, value: QVariant::fromValue<QPointF>(value: pos)));
3870 QPointF newPos = newPosVariant.toPointF();
3871 if (newPos == d_ptr->pos)
3872 return;
3873
3874 // Update and repositition.
3875 d_ptr->setPosHelper(newPos);
3876
3877 // Send post-notification.
3878 itemChange(change: QGraphicsItem::ItemPositionHasChanged, value: newPosVariant);
3879 d_ptr->sendScenePosChange();
3880}
3881
3882/*!
3883 \fn void QGraphicsItem::setPos(qreal x, qreal y)
3884 \overload
3885
3886 This convenience function is equivalent to calling setPos(QPointF(\a x, \a
3887 y)).
3888*/
3889
3890/*!
3891 \fn void QGraphicsItem::moveBy(qreal dx, qreal dy)
3892
3893 Moves the item by \a dx points horizontally, and \a dy point
3894 vertically. This function is equivalent to calling setPos(pos() +
3895 QPointF(\a dx, \a dy)).
3896*/
3897
3898/*!
3899 If this item is part of a scene that is viewed by a QGraphicsView, this
3900 convenience function will attempt to scroll the view to ensure that \a
3901 rect is visible inside the view's viewport. If \a rect is a null rect (the
3902 default), QGraphicsItem will default to the item's bounding rect. \a xmargin
3903 and \a ymargin are the number of pixels the view should use for margins.
3904
3905 If the specified rect cannot be reached, the contents are scrolled to the
3906 nearest valid position.
3907
3908 If this item is not viewed by a QGraphicsView, this function does nothing.
3909
3910 \sa QGraphicsView::ensureVisible()
3911*/
3912void QGraphicsItem::ensureVisible(const QRectF &rect, int xmargin, int ymargin)
3913{
3914 if (d_ptr->scene) {
3915 QRectF sceneRect;
3916 if (!rect.isNull())
3917 sceneRect = sceneTransform().mapRect(rect);
3918 else
3919 sceneRect = sceneBoundingRect();
3920 for (QGraphicsView *view : std::as_const(t&: d_ptr->scene->d_func()->views))
3921 view->ensureVisible(rect: sceneRect, xmargin, ymargin);
3922 }
3923}
3924
3925/*!
3926 \fn void QGraphicsItem::ensureVisible(qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h,
3927 int xmargin = 50, int ymargin = 50)
3928
3929 This convenience function is equivalent to calling
3930 ensureVisible(QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h), \a xmargin, \a ymargin).
3931*/
3932
3933/*!
3934 \since 4.3
3935
3936 Returns this item's transformation matrix.
3937
3938 The transformation matrix is combined with the item's rotation(), scale()
3939 and transformations() into a combined transformations for the item.
3940
3941 The default transformation matrix is an identity matrix.
3942
3943 \sa setTransform(), sceneTransform()
3944*/
3945QTransform QGraphicsItem::transform() const
3946{
3947 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
3948 return QTransform();
3949 return d_ptr->transformData->transform;
3950}
3951
3952/*!
3953 \since 4.6
3954
3955 Returns the clockwise rotation, in degrees, around the Z axis. The default
3956 value is 0 (i.e., the item is not rotated).
3957
3958 The rotation is combined with the item's scale(), transform() and
3959 transformations() to map the item's coordinate system to the parent item.
3960
3961 \sa setRotation(), transformOriginPoint(), {Transformations}
3962*/
3963qreal QGraphicsItem::rotation() const
3964{
3965 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
3966 return 0;
3967 return d_ptr->transformData->rotation;
3968}
3969
3970/*!
3971 \since 4.6
3972
3973 Sets the clockwise rotation \a angle, in degrees, around the Z axis. The
3974 default value is 0 (i.e., the item is not rotated). Assigning a negative
3975 value will rotate the item counter-clockwise. Normally the rotation angle
3976 is in the range (-360, 360), but it's also possible to assign values
3977 outside of this range (e.g., a rotation of 370 degrees is the same as a
3978 rotation of 10 degrees).
3979
3980 The item is rotated around its transform origin point, which by default
3981 is (0, 0). You can select a different transformation origin by calling
3982 setTransformOriginPoint().
3983
3984 The rotation is combined with the item's scale(), transform() and
3985 transformations() to map the item's coordinate system to the parent item.
3986
3987 \sa rotation(), setTransformOriginPoint(), {Transformations}
3988*/
3989void QGraphicsItem::setRotation(qreal angle)
3990{
3991 prepareGeometryChange();
3992 qreal newRotation = angle;
3993
3994 if (d_ptr->flags & ItemSendsGeometryChanges) {
3995 // Notify the item that the rotation is changing.
3996 const QVariant newRotationVariant(itemChange(change: ItemRotationChange, value: angle));
3997 newRotation = newRotationVariant.toReal();
3998 }
3999
4000 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
4001 d_ptr->transformData = new QGraphicsItemPrivate::TransformData;
4002
4003 if (d_ptr->transformData->rotation == newRotation)
4004 return;
4005
4006 d_ptr->transformData->rotation = newRotation;
4007 d_ptr->transformData->onlyTransform = false;
4008 d_ptr->dirtySceneTransform = 1;
4009
4010 // Send post-notification.
4011 if (d_ptr->flags & ItemSendsGeometryChanges)
4012 itemChange(change: ItemRotationHasChanged, value: newRotation);
4013
4014 if (d_ptr->isObject)
4015 emit static_cast<QGraphicsObject *>(this)->rotationChanged();
4016
4017 d_ptr->transformChanged();
4018}
4019
4020/*!
4021 \since 4.6
4022
4023 Returns the scale factor of the item. The default scale factor is 1.0
4024 (i.e., the item is not scaled).
4025
4026 The scale is combined with the item's rotation(), transform() and
4027 transformations() to map the item's coordinate system to the parent item.
4028
4029 \sa setScale(), rotation(), {Transformations}
4030*/
4031qreal QGraphicsItem::scale() const
4032{
4033 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
4034 return 1.;
4035 return d_ptr->transformData->scale;
4036}
4037
4038/*!
4039 \since 4.6
4040
4041 Sets the scale \a factor of the item. The default scale factor is 1.0
4042 (i.e., the item is not scaled). A scale factor of 0.0 will collapse the
4043 item to a single point. If you provide a negative scale factor, the
4044 item will be flipped and mirrored (i.e., rotated 180 degrees).
4045
4046 The item is scaled around its transform origin point, which by default
4047 is (0, 0). You can select a different transformation origin by calling
4048 setTransformOriginPoint().
4049
4050 The scale is combined with the item's rotation(), transform() and
4051 transformations() to map the item's coordinate system to the parent item.
4052
4053 \sa scale(), setTransformOriginPoint(), {Transformations Example}
4054*/
4055void QGraphicsItem::setScale(qreal factor)
4056{
4057 prepareGeometryChange();
4058 qreal newScale = factor;
4059
4060 if (d_ptr->flags & ItemSendsGeometryChanges) {
4061 // Notify the item that the scale is changing.
4062 const QVariant newScaleVariant(itemChange(change: ItemScaleChange, value: factor));
4063 newScale = newScaleVariant.toReal();
4064 }
4065
4066 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
4067 d_ptr->transformData = new QGraphicsItemPrivate::TransformData;
4068
4069 if (d_ptr->transformData->scale == newScale)
4070 return;
4071
4072 d_ptr->transformData->scale = newScale;
4073 d_ptr->transformData->onlyTransform = false;
4074 d_ptr->dirtySceneTransform = 1;
4075
4076 // Send post-notification.
4077 if (d_ptr->flags & ItemSendsGeometryChanges)
4078 itemChange(change: ItemScaleHasChanged, value: newScale);
4079
4080 if (d_ptr->isObject)
4081 emit static_cast<QGraphicsObject *>(this)->scaleChanged();
4082
4083 d_ptr->transformChanged();
4084}
4085
4086
4087/*!
4088 \since 4.6
4089
4090 Returns a list of graphics transforms that currently apply to this item.
4091
4092 QGraphicsTransform is for applying and controlling a chain of individual
4093 transformation operations on an item. It's particularly useful in
4094 animations, where each transform operation needs to be interpolated
4095 independently, or differently.
4096
4097 The transformations are combined with the item's rotation(), scale() and
4098 transform() to map the item's coordinate system to the parent item.
4099
4100 \sa scale(), rotation(), transformOriginPoint(), {Transformations}
4101*/
4102QList<QGraphicsTransform *> QGraphicsItem::transformations() const
4103{
4104 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
4105 return QList<QGraphicsTransform *>();
4106 return d_ptr->transformData->graphicsTransforms;
4107}
4108
4109/*!
4110 \since 4.6
4111
4112 Sets a list of graphics \a transformations (QGraphicsTransform) that
4113 currently apply to this item.
4114
4115 If all you want is to rotate or scale an item, you should call setRotation()
4116 or setScale() instead. If you want to set an arbitrary transformation on
4117 an item, you can call setTransform().
4118
4119 QGraphicsTransform is for applying and controlling a chain of individual
4120 transformation operations on an item. It's particularly useful in
4121 animations, where each transform operation needs to be interpolated
4122 independently, or differently.
4123
4124 The transformations are combined with the item's rotation(), scale() and
4125 transform() to map the item's coordinate system to the parent item.
4126
4127 \sa scale(), setTransformOriginPoint(), {Transformations}
4128*/
4129void QGraphicsItem::setTransformations(const QList<QGraphicsTransform *> &transformations)
4130{
4131 prepareGeometryChange();
4132 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
4133 d_ptr->transformData = new QGraphicsItemPrivate::TransformData;
4134 d_ptr->transformData->graphicsTransforms = transformations;
4135 for (int i = 0; i < transformations.size(); ++i)
4136 transformations.at(i)->d_func()->setItem(this);
4137 d_ptr->transformData->onlyTransform = false;
4138 d_ptr->dirtySceneTransform = 1;
4139 d_ptr->transformChanged();
4140}
4141
4142/*!
4143 \internal
4144*/
4145void QGraphicsItemPrivate::prependGraphicsTransform(QGraphicsTransform *t)
4146{
4147 if (!transformData)
4148 transformData = new QGraphicsItemPrivate::TransformData;
4149 if (!transformData->graphicsTransforms.contains(t))
4150 transformData->graphicsTransforms.prepend(t);
4151
4152 Q_Q(QGraphicsItem);
4153 t->d_func()->setItem(q);
4154 transformData->onlyTransform = false;
4155 dirtySceneTransform = 1;
4156 transformChanged();
4157}
4158
4159/*!
4160 \internal
4161*/
4162void QGraphicsItemPrivate::appendGraphicsTransform(QGraphicsTransform *t)
4163{
4164 if (!transformData)
4165 transformData = new QGraphicsItemPrivate::TransformData;
4166 if (!transformData->graphicsTransforms.contains(t))
4167 transformData->graphicsTransforms.append(t);
4168
4169 Q_Q(QGraphicsItem);
4170 t->d_func()->setItem(q);
4171 transformData->onlyTransform = false;
4172 dirtySceneTransform = 1;
4173 transformChanged();
4174}
4175
4176/*!
4177 \since 4.6
4178
4179 Returns the origin point for the transformation in item coordinates.
4180
4181 The default is QPointF(0,0).
4182
4183 \sa setTransformOriginPoint(), {Transformations}
4184*/
4185QPointF QGraphicsItem::transformOriginPoint() const
4186{
4187 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
4188 return QPointF(0,0);
4189 return QPointF(d_ptr->transformData->xOrigin, d_ptr->transformData->yOrigin);
4190}
4191
4192/*!
4193 \since 4.6
4194
4195 Sets the \a origin point for the transformation in item coordinates.
4196
4197 \sa transformOriginPoint(), {Transformations}
4198*/
4199void QGraphicsItem::setTransformOriginPoint(const QPointF &origin)
4200{
4201 prepareGeometryChange();
4202 QPointF newOrigin = origin;
4203
4204 if (d_ptr->flags & ItemSendsGeometryChanges) {
4205 // Notify the item that the origin point is changing.
4206 const QVariant newOriginVariant(itemChange(change: ItemTransformOriginPointChange,
4207 value: QVariant::fromValue<QPointF>(value: origin)));
4208 newOrigin = newOriginVariant.toPointF();
4209 }
4210
4211 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
4212 d_ptr->transformData = new QGraphicsItemPrivate::TransformData;
4213
4214 if (d_ptr->transformData->xOrigin == newOrigin.x()
4215 && d_ptr->transformData->yOrigin == newOrigin.y()) {
4216 return;
4217 }
4218
4219 d_ptr->transformData->xOrigin = newOrigin.x();
4220 d_ptr->transformData->yOrigin = newOrigin.y();
4221 d_ptr->transformData->onlyTransform = false;
4222 d_ptr->dirtySceneTransform = 1;
4223
4224 // Send post-notification.
4225 if (d_ptr->flags & ItemSendsGeometryChanges)
4226 itemChange(change: ItemTransformOriginPointHasChanged, value: QVariant::fromValue<QPointF>(value: newOrigin));
4227}
4228
4229/*!
4230 \fn void QGraphicsItem::setTransformOriginPoint(qreal x, qreal y)
4231
4232 \since 4.6
4233 \overload
4234
4235 Sets the origin point for the transformation in item coordinates.
4236 This is equivalent to calling setTransformOriginPoint(QPointF(\a x, \a y)).
4237
4238 \sa setTransformOriginPoint(), {Transformations}
4239*/
4240
4241/*!
4242 \since 4.3
4243
4244 Returns this item's scene transformation matrix. This matrix can be used
4245 to map coordinates and geometrical shapes from this item's local
4246 coordinate system to the scene's coordinate system. To map coordinates
4247 from the scene, you must first invert the returned matrix.
4248
4249 Example:
4250
4251 \snippet code/src_gui_graphicsview_qgraphicsitem.cpp 4
4252
4253 Unlike transform(), which returns only an item's local transformation, this
4254 function includes the item's (and any parents') position, and all the
4255 transformation properties.
4256
4257 \sa transform(), setTransform(), scenePos(), {The Graphics View Coordinate System}, {Transformations}
4258*/
4259QTransform QGraphicsItem::sceneTransform() const
4260{
4261 d_ptr->ensureSceneTransform();
4262 return d_ptr->sceneTransform;
4263}
4264
4265/*!
4266 \since 4.3
4267
4268 Returns this item's device transformation matrix, using \a
4269 viewportTransform to map from scene to device coordinates. This matrix can
4270 be used to map coordinates and geometrical shapes from this item's local
4271 coordinate system to the viewport's (or any device's) coordinate
4272 system. To map coordinates from the viewport, you must first invert the
4273 returned matrix.
4274
4275 Example:
4276
4277 \snippet code/src_gui_graphicsview_qgraphicsitem.cpp 5
4278
4279 This function is the same as combining this item's scene transform with
4280 the view's viewport transform, but it also understands the
4281 ItemIgnoresTransformations flag. The device transform can be used to do
4282 accurate coordinate mapping (and collision detection) for untransformable
4283 items.
4284
4285 \sa transform(), setTransform(), scenePos(), {The Graphics View Coordinate
4286 System}, itemTransform()
4287*/
4288QTransform QGraphicsItem::deviceTransform(const QTransform &viewportTransform) const
4289{
4290 // Ensure we return the standard transform if we're not untransformable.
4291 if (!d_ptr->itemIsUntransformable()) {
4292 d_ptr->ensureSceneTransform();
4293 return d_ptr->sceneTransform * viewportTransform;
4294 }
4295
4296 // Find the topmost item that ignores view transformations.
4297 const QGraphicsItem *untransformedAncestor = this;
4298 QList<const QGraphicsItem *> parents;
4299 while (untransformedAncestor && ((untransformedAncestor->d_ptr->ancestorFlags
4300 & QGraphicsItemPrivate::AncestorIgnoresTransformations))) {
4301 parents.prepend(t: untransformedAncestor);
4302 untransformedAncestor = untransformedAncestor->parentItem();
4303 }
4304
4305 if (!untransformedAncestor) {
4306 // Assert in debug mode, continue in release.
4307 Q_ASSERT_X(untransformedAncestor, "QGraphicsItem::deviceTransform",
4308 "Invalid object structure!");
4309 return QTransform();
4310 }
4311
4312 // Determine the inherited origin. Find the parent of the topmost untransformable.
4313 // Use its scene transform to map the position of the untransformable. Then use
4314 // that viewport position as the anchoring point for the untransformable subtree.
4315 QGraphicsItem *parentOfUntransformedAncestor = untransformedAncestor->parentItem();
4316 QTransform inheritedMatrix;
4317 if (parentOfUntransformedAncestor)
4318 inheritedMatrix = parentOfUntransformedAncestor->sceneTransform();
4319 QPointF mappedPoint = (inheritedMatrix * viewportTransform).map(p: untransformedAncestor->pos());
4320
4321 // COMBINE
4322 QTransform matrix = QTransform::fromTranslate(dx: mappedPoint.x(), dy: mappedPoint.y());
4323 if (untransformedAncestor->d_ptr->transformData)
4324 matrix = untransformedAncestor->d_ptr->transformData->computedFullTransform(postmultiplyTransform: &matrix);
4325
4326 // Then transform and translate all children.
4327 for (int i = 0; i < parents.size(); ++i) {
4328 const QGraphicsItem *parent = parents.at(i);
4329 parent->d_ptr->combineTransformFromParent(x: &matrix);
4330 }
4331
4332 return matrix;
4333}
4334
4335/*!
4336 \since 4.5
4337
4338 Returns a QTransform that maps coordinates from this item to \a other. If
4339 \a ok is not null, and if there is no such transform, the boolean pointed
4340 to by \a ok will be set to false; otherwise it will be set to true.
4341
4342 This transform provides an alternative to the mapToItem() or mapFromItem()
4343 functions, by returning the appropriate transform so that you can map
4344 shapes and coordinates yourself. It also helps you write more efficient
4345 code when repeatedly mapping between the same two items.
4346
4347 \note In rare circumstances, there is no transform that maps between two
4348 items.
4349
4350 \sa mapToItem(), mapFromItem(), deviceTransform()
4351*/
4352QTransform QGraphicsItem::itemTransform(const QGraphicsItem *other, bool *ok) const
4353{
4354 // Catch simple cases first.
4355 if (other == nullptr) {
4356 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::itemTransform: null pointer passed");
4357 return QTransform();
4358 }
4359 if (other == this) {
4360 if (ok)
4361 *ok = true;
4362 return QTransform();
4363 }
4364
4365 QGraphicsItem *parent = d_ptr->parent;
4366 const QGraphicsItem *otherParent = other->d_ptr->parent;
4367
4368 // This is other's child
4369 if (parent == other) {
4370 if (ok)
4371 *ok = true;
4372 QTransform x;
4373 d_ptr->combineTransformFromParent(x: &x);
4374 return x;
4375 }
4376
4377 // This is other's parent
4378 if (otherParent == this) {
4379 const QPointF &otherPos = other->d_ptr->pos;
4380 if (other->d_ptr->transformData) {
4381 QTransform otherToParent;
4382 other->d_ptr->combineTransformFromParent(x: &otherToParent);
4383 return otherToParent.inverted(invertible: ok);
4384 }
4385 if (ok)
4386 *ok = true;
4387 return QTransform::fromTranslate(dx: -otherPos.x(), dy: -otherPos.y());
4388 }
4389
4390 // Siblings
4391 if (parent == otherParent) {
4392 // COMBINE
4393 const QPointF &itemPos = d_ptr->pos;
4394 const QPointF &otherPos = other->d_ptr->pos;
