4395 if (!d_ptr->transformData && !other->d_ptr->transformData) {
4396 QPointF delta = itemPos - otherPos;
4397 if (ok)
4398 *ok = true;
4399 return QTransform::fromTranslate(dx: delta.x(), dy: delta.y());
4400 }
4401
4402 QTransform itemToParent;
4403 d_ptr->combineTransformFromParent(x: &itemToParent);
4404 QTransform otherToParent;
4405 other->d_ptr->combineTransformFromParent(x: &otherToParent);
4406 return itemToParent * otherToParent.inverted(invertible: ok);
4407 }
4408
4409 // Find the closest common ancestor. If the two items don't share an
4410 // ancestor, then the only way is to combine their scene transforms.
4411 const QGraphicsItem *commonAncestor = commonAncestorItem(other);
4412 if (!commonAncestor) {
4413 d_ptr->ensureSceneTransform();
4414 other->d_ptr->ensureSceneTransform();
4415 return d_ptr->sceneTransform * other->d_ptr->sceneTransform.inverted(invertible: ok);
4416 }
4417
4418 // If the two items are cousins (in sibling branches), map both to the
4419 // common ancestor, and combine the two transforms.
4420 bool cousins = other != commonAncestor && this != commonAncestor;
4421 if (cousins) {
4422 bool good = false;
4423 QTransform thisToScene = itemTransform(other: commonAncestor, ok: &good);
4424 QTransform otherToScene(Qt::Uninitialized);
4425 if (good)
4426 otherToScene = other->itemTransform(other: commonAncestor, ok: &good);
4427 if (!good) {
4428 if (ok)
4429 *ok = false;
4430 return QTransform();
4431 }
4432 return thisToScene * otherToScene.inverted(invertible: ok);
4433 }
4434
4435 // One is an ancestor of the other; walk the chain.
4436 bool parentOfOther = isAncestorOf(child: other);
4437 const QGraphicsItem *child = parentOfOther ? other : this;
4438 const QGraphicsItem *root = parentOfOther ? this : other;
4439
4440 QTransform x;
4441 const QGraphicsItem *p = child;
4442 do {
4443 p->d_ptr.data()->combineTransformToParent(x: &x);
4444 } while ((p = p->d_ptr->parent) && p != root);
4445 if (parentOfOther)
4446 return x.inverted(invertible: ok);
4447 if (ok)
4448 *ok = true;
4449 return x;
4450}
4451
4452/*!
4453 \since 4.3
4454
4455 Sets the item's current transformation matrix to \a matrix.
4456
4457 If \a combine is true, then \a matrix is combined with the current matrix;
4458 otherwise, \a matrix \e replaces the current matrix. \a combine is false
4459 by default.
4460
4461 To simplify interaction with items using a transformed view, QGraphicsItem
4462 provides mapTo... and mapFrom... functions that can translate between
4463 items' and the scene's coordinates. For example, you can call mapToScene()
4464 to map an item coordinate to a scene coordinate, or mapFromScene() to map
4465 from scene coordinates to item coordinates.
4466
4467 The transformation matrix is combined with the item's rotation(), scale()
4468 and transformations() into a combined transformation that maps the item's
4469 coordinate system to its parent.
4470
4471 \sa transform(), setRotation(), setScale(), setTransformOriginPoint(), {The Graphics View Coordinate System}, {Transformations}
4472*/
4473void QGraphicsItem::setTransform(const QTransform &matrix, bool combine)
4474{
4475 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
4476 d_ptr->transformData = new QGraphicsItemPrivate::TransformData;
4477
4478 QTransform newTransform(combine ? matrix * d_ptr->transformData->transform : matrix);
4479 if (d_ptr->transformData->transform == newTransform)
4480 return;
4481
4482 // Update and set the new transformation.
4483 if (!(d_ptr->flags & (ItemSendsGeometryChanges | ItemSendsScenePositionChanges))) {
4484 d_ptr->setTransformHelper(newTransform);
4485 if (d_ptr->scenePosDescendants)
4486 d_ptr->sendScenePosChange();
4487 return;
4488 }
4489
4490 // Notify the item that the transformation matrix is changing.
4491 const QVariant newTransformVariant(itemChange(change: ItemTransformChange,
4492 value: QVariant::fromValue<QTransform>(value: newTransform)));
4493 newTransform = qvariant_cast<QTransform>(v: newTransformVariant);
4494 if (d_ptr->transformData->transform == newTransform)
4495 return;
4496
4497 // Update and set the new transformation.
4498 d_ptr->setTransformHelper(newTransform);
4499
4500 // Send post-notification.
4501 itemChange(change: ItemTransformHasChanged, value: newTransformVariant);
4502 d_ptr->sendScenePosChange();
4503}
4504
4505/*!
4506 \since 4.3
4507
4508 Resets this item's transformation matrix to the identity matrix or
4509 all the transformation properties to their default values.
4510 This is equivalent to calling \c setTransform(QTransform()).
4511
4512 \sa setTransform(), transform()
4513*/
4514void QGraphicsItem::resetTransform()
4515{
4516 setTransform(matrix: QTransform(), combine: false);
4517}
4518
4519/*!
4520 This virtual function is called twice for all items by the
4521 QGraphicsScene::advance() slot. In the first phase, all items are called
4522 with \a phase == 0, indicating that items on the scene are about to
4523 advance, and then all items are called with \a phase == 1. Reimplement
4524 this function to update your item if you need simple scene-controlled
4525 animation.
4526
4527 The default implementation does nothing.
4528
4529 This function is intended for animations. An alternative is to
4530 multiple-inherit from QObject and QGraphicsItem and use the \l{The Animation
4531 Framework}{Animation Framework}.
4532
4533 \sa QGraphicsScene::advance(), QTimeLine
4534*/
4535void QGraphicsItem::advance(int phase)
4536{
4537 Q_UNUSED(phase);
4538}
4539
4540/*!
4541 Returns the Z-value of the item. The Z-value affects the stacking order of
4542 sibling (neighboring) items.
4543
4544 The default Z-value is 0.
4545
4546 \sa setZValue(), {QGraphicsItem#Sorting}{Sorting}, stackBefore(), ItemStacksBehindParent
4547*/
4548qreal QGraphicsItem::zValue() const
4549{
4550 return d_ptr->z;
4551}
4552
4553/*!
4554 Sets the Z-value of the item to \a z. The Z value decides the stacking
4555 order of sibling (neighboring) items. A sibling item of high Z value will
4556 always be drawn on top of another sibling item with a lower Z value.
4557
4558 If you restore the Z value, the item's insertion order will decide its
4559 stacking order.
4560
4561 The Z-value does not affect the item's size in any way.
4562
4563 The default Z-value is 0.
4564
4565 \sa zValue(), {QGraphicsItem#Sorting}{Sorting}, stackBefore(), ItemStacksBehindParent
4566*/
4567void QGraphicsItem::setZValue(qreal z)
4568{
4569 const QVariant newZVariant(itemChange(change: ItemZValueChange, value: z));
4570 qreal newZ = newZVariant.toReal();
4571 if (newZ == d_ptr->z)
4572 return;
4573
4574 if (d_ptr->scene && d_ptr->scene->d_func()->indexMethod != QGraphicsScene::NoIndex) {
4575 // Z Value has changed, we have to notify the index.
4576 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->index->itemChange(item: this, ItemZValueChange, value: &newZ);
4577 }
4578
4579 d_ptr->z = newZ;
4580 if (d_ptr->parent)
4581 d_ptr->parent->d_ptr->needSortChildren = 1;
4582 else if (d_ptr->scene)
4583 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->needSortTopLevelItems = 1;
4584
4585 if (d_ptr->scene)
4586 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->markDirty(item: this, rect: QRectF(), /*invalidateChildren=*/true);
4587
4588 itemChange(change: ItemZValueHasChanged, value: newZVariant);
4589
4590 if (d_ptr->flags & ItemNegativeZStacksBehindParent)
4591 setFlag(flag: QGraphicsItem::ItemStacksBehindParent, enabled: z < qreal(0.0));
4592
4593 if (d_ptr->isObject)
4594 emit static_cast<QGraphicsObject *>(this)->zChanged();
4595}
4596
4597/*!
4598 \internal
4599
4600 Ensures that the list of children is sorted by insertion order, and that
4601 the siblingIndexes are packed (no gaps), and start at 0.
4602
4603 ### This function is almost identical to
4604 QGraphicsScenePrivate::ensureSequentialTopLevelSiblingIndexes().
4605*/
4606void QGraphicsItemPrivate::ensureSequentialSiblingIndex()
4607{
4608 if (!sequentialOrdering) {
4609 std::sort(first: children.begin(), last: children.end(), comp: insertionOrder);
4610 sequentialOrdering = 1;
4611 needSortChildren = 1;
4612 }
4613 if (holesInSiblingIndex) {
4614 holesInSiblingIndex = 0;
4615 for (int i = 0; i < children.size(); ++i)
4616 children[i]->d_ptr->siblingIndex = i;
4617 }
4618}
4619
4620/*!
4621 \internal
4622*/
4623inline void QGraphicsItemPrivate::sendScenePosChange()
4624{
4625 Q_Q(QGraphicsItem);
4626 if (scene) {
4627 if (flags & QGraphicsItem::ItemSendsScenePositionChanges)
4628 q->itemChange(change: QGraphicsItem::ItemScenePositionHasChanged, value: q->scenePos());
4629 if (scenePosDescendants) {
4630 for (QGraphicsItem *item : std::as_const(t&: scene->d_func()->scenePosItems)) {
4631 if (q->isAncestorOf(child: item))
4632 item->itemChange(change: QGraphicsItem::ItemScenePositionHasChanged, value: item->scenePos());
4633 }
4634 }
4635 }
4636}
4637
4638/*!
4639 \since 4.6
4640
4641 Stacks this item before \a sibling, which must be a sibling item (i.e., the
4642 two items must share the same parent item, or must both be toplevel items).
4643 The \a sibling must have the same Z value as this item, otherwise calling
4644 this function will have no effect.
4645
4646 By default, all sibling items are stacked by insertion order (i.e., the
4647 first item you add is drawn before the next item you add). If two items' Z
4648 values are different, then the item with the highest Z value is drawn on
4649 top. When the Z values are the same, the insertion order will decide the
4650 stacking order.
4651
4652 \sa setZValue(), ItemStacksBehindParent, {QGraphicsItem#Sorting}{Sorting}
4653*/
4654void QGraphicsItem::stackBefore(const QGraphicsItem *sibling)
4655{
4656 if (sibling == this)
4657 return;
4658 if (!sibling || d_ptr->parent != sibling->parentItem()) {
4659 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::stackUnder: cannot stack under %p, which must be a sibling", sibling);
4660 return;
4661 }
4662 QList<QGraphicsItem *> *siblings = d_ptr->parent
4663 ? &d_ptr->parent->d_ptr->children
4664 : (d_ptr->scene ? &d_ptr->scene->d_func()->topLevelItems : nullptr);
4665 if (!siblings) {
4666 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::stackUnder: cannot stack under %p, which must be a sibling", sibling);
4667 return;
4668 }
4669
4670 // First, make sure that the sibling indexes have no holes. This also
4671 // marks the children list for sorting.
4672 if (d_ptr->parent)
4673 d_ptr->parent->d_ptr->ensureSequentialSiblingIndex();
4674 else
4675 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->ensureSequentialTopLevelSiblingIndexes();
4676
4677 // Only move items with the same Z value, and that need moving.
4678 int siblingIndex = sibling->d_ptr->siblingIndex;
4679 int myIndex = d_ptr->siblingIndex;
4680 if (myIndex >= siblingIndex) {
4681 siblings->move(from: myIndex, to: siblingIndex);
4682 // Fixup the insertion ordering.
4683 for (int i = 0; i < siblings->size(); ++i) {
4684 int &index = siblings->at(i)->d_ptr->siblingIndex;
4685 if (i != siblingIndex && index >= siblingIndex && index <= myIndex)
4686 ++index;
4687 }
4688 d_ptr->siblingIndex = siblingIndex;
4689 for (int i = 0; i < siblings->size(); ++i) {
4690 int &index = siblings->at(i)->d_ptr->siblingIndex;
4691 if (i != siblingIndex && index >= siblingIndex && index <= myIndex)
4692 siblings->at(i)->d_ptr->siblingOrderChange();
4693 }
4694 d_ptr->siblingOrderChange();
4695 }
4696}
4697
4698/*!
4699 Returns the bounding rect of this item's descendants (i.e., its
4700 children, their children, etc.) in local coordinates. The
4701 rectangle will contain all descendants after they have been mapped
4702 to local coordinates. If the item has no children, this function
4703 returns an empty QRectF.
4704
4705 This does not include this item's own bounding rect; it only returns
4706 its descendants' accumulated bounding rect. If you need to include this
4707 item's bounding rect, you can add boundingRect() to childrenBoundingRect()
4708 using QRectF::operator|().
4709
4710 This function is linear in complexity; it determines the size of the
4711 returned bounding rect by iterating through all descendants.
4712
4713 \sa boundingRect(), sceneBoundingRect()
4714*/
4715QRectF QGraphicsItem::childrenBoundingRect() const
4716{
4717 if (!d_ptr->dirtyChildrenBoundingRect)
4718 return d_ptr->childrenBoundingRect;
4719
4720 d_ptr->childrenBoundingRect = QRectF();
4721 d_ptr->childrenBoundingRectHelper(x: nullptr, rect: &d_ptr->childrenBoundingRect, topMostEffectItem: nullptr);
4722 d_ptr->dirtyChildrenBoundingRect = 0;
4723 return d_ptr->childrenBoundingRect;
4724}
4725
4726/*!
4727 \fn virtual QRectF QGraphicsItem::boundingRect() const = 0
4728
4729 This pure virtual function defines the outer bounds of the item as
4730 a rectangle; all painting must be restricted to inside an item's
4731 bounding rect. QGraphicsView uses this to determine whether the
4732 item requires redrawing.
4733
4734 Although the item's shape can be arbitrary, the bounding rect is
4735 always rectangular, and it is unaffected by the items'
4736 transformation.
4737
4738 If you want to change the item's bounding rectangle, you must first call
4739 prepareGeometryChange(). This notifies the scene of the imminent change,
4740 so that it can update its item geometry index; otherwise, the scene will
4741 be unaware of the item's new geometry, and the results are undefined
4742 (typically, rendering artifacts are left within the view).
4743
4744 Reimplement this function to let QGraphicsView determine what
4745 parts of the widget, if any, need to be redrawn.
4746
4747 Note: For shapes that paint an outline / stroke, it is important
4748 to include half the pen width in the bounding rect. It is not
4749 necessary to compensate for antialiasing, though.
4750
4751 Example:
4752
4753 \snippet code/src_gui_graphicsview_qgraphicsitem.cpp 8
4754
4755 \sa boundingRegion(), shape(), contains(), {The Graphics View Coordinate
4756 System}, prepareGeometryChange()
4757*/
4758
4759/*!
4760 Returns the bounding rect of this item in scene coordinates, by combining
4761 sceneTransform() with boundingRect().
4762
4763 \sa boundingRect(), {The Graphics View Coordinate System}
4764*/
4765QRectF QGraphicsItem::sceneBoundingRect() const
4766{
4767 // Find translate-only offset
4768 // COMBINE
4769 QPointF offset;
4770 const QGraphicsItem *parentItem = this;
4771 const QGraphicsItemPrivate *itemd;
4772 do {
4773 itemd = parentItem->d_ptr.data();
4774 if (itemd->transformData)
4775 break;
4776 offset += itemd->pos;
4777 } while ((parentItem = itemd->parent));
4778
4779 QRectF br = boundingRect();
4780 br.translate(p: offset);
4781 if (!parentItem)
4782 return br;
4783 if (parentItem->d_ptr->hasTranslateOnlySceneTransform()) {
4784 br.translate(dx: parentItem->d_ptr->sceneTransform.dx(), dy: parentItem->d_ptr->sceneTransform.dy());
4785 return br;
4786 }
4787 return parentItem->d_ptr->sceneTransform.mapRect(br);
4788}
4789
4790/*!
4791 Returns the shape of this item as a QPainterPath in local
4792 coordinates. The shape is used for many things, including collision
4793 detection, hit tests, and for the QGraphicsScene::items() functions.
4794
4795 The default implementation calls boundingRect() to return a simple
4796 rectangular shape, but subclasses can reimplement this function to return
4797 a more accurate shape for non-rectangular items. For example, a round item
4798 may choose to return an elliptic shape for better collision detection. For
4799 example:
4800
4801 \snippet code/src_gui_graphicsview_qgraphicsitem.cpp 9
4802
4803 The outline of a shape can vary depending on the width and style of the
4804 pen used when drawing. If you want to include this outline in the item's
4805 shape, you can create a shape from the stroke using QPainterPathStroker.
4806
4807 This function is called by the default implementations of contains() and
4808 collidesWithPath().
4809
4810 \sa boundingRect(), contains(), prepareGeometryChange(), QPainterPathStroker
4811*/
4812QPainterPath QGraphicsItem::shape() const
4813{
4814 QPainterPath path;
4815 path.addRect(rect: boundingRect());
4816 return path;
4817}
4818
4819/*!
4820 Returns \c true if this item is clipped. An item is clipped if it has either
4821 set the \l ItemClipsToShape flag, or if it or any of its ancestors has set
4822 the \l ItemClipsChildrenToShape flag.
4823
4824 Clipping affects the item's appearance (i.e., painting), as well as mouse
4825 and hover event delivery.
4826
4827 \sa clipPath(), shape(), setFlags()
4828*/
4829bool QGraphicsItem::isClipped() const
4830{
4831 Q_D(const QGraphicsItem);
4832 return (d->ancestorFlags & QGraphicsItemPrivate::AncestorClipsChildren)
4833 || (d->flags & QGraphicsItem::ItemClipsToShape);
4834}
4835
4836/*!
4837 \since 4.5
4838
4839 Returns this item's clip path, or an empty QPainterPath if this item is
4840 not clipped. The clip path constrains the item's appearance and
4841 interaction (i.e., restricts the area the item can draw within and receive
4842 events for).
4843
4844 You can enable clipping by setting the ItemClipsToShape or
4845 ItemClipsChildrenToShape flags. The item's clip path is calculated by
4846 intersecting all clipping ancestors' shapes. If the item sets
4847 ItemClipsToShape, the final clip is intersected with the item's own shape.
4848
4849 \note Clipping introduces a performance penalty for all items involved;
4850 you should generally avoid using clipping if you can (e.g., if your items
4851 always draw inside boundingRect() or shape() boundaries, clipping is not
4852 necessary).
4853
4854 \sa isClipped(), shape(), setFlags()
4855*/
4856QPainterPath QGraphicsItem::clipPath() const
4857{
4858 Q_D(const QGraphicsItem);
4859 if (!isClipped())
4860 return QPainterPath();
4861
4862 const QRectF thisBoundingRect(boundingRect());
4863 if (thisBoundingRect.isEmpty())
4864 return QPainterPath();
4865
4866 QPainterPath clip;
4867 // Start with the item's bounding rect.
4868 clip.addRect(rect: thisBoundingRect);
4869
4870 if (d->ancestorFlags & QGraphicsItemPrivate::AncestorClipsChildren) {
4871 const QGraphicsItem *parent = this;
4872 const QGraphicsItem *lastParent = this;
4873
4874 // Intersect any in-between clips starting at the top and moving downwards.
4875 while ((parent = parent->d_ptr->parent)) {
4876 if (parent->d_ptr->flags & ItemClipsChildrenToShape) {
4877 // Map clip to the current parent and intersect with its shape/clipPath
4878 clip = lastParent->itemTransform(other: parent).map(p: clip);
4879 clip = clip.intersected(r: parent->shape());
4880 if (clip.isEmpty())
4881 return clip;
4882 lastParent = parent;
4883 }
4884
4885 if (!(parent->d_ptr->ancestorFlags & QGraphicsItemPrivate::AncestorClipsChildren))
4886 break;
4887 }
4888
4889 if (lastParent != this) {
4890 // Map clip back to the item's transform.
4891 // ### what if itemtransform fails
4892 clip = lastParent->itemTransform(other: this).map(p: clip);
4893 }
4894 }
4895
4896 if (d->flags & ItemClipsToShape)
4897 clip = clip.intersected(r: shape());
4898
4899 return clip;
4900}
4901
4902/*!
4903 Returns \c true if this item contains \a point, which is in local
4904 coordinates; otherwise, false is returned. It is most often called from
4905 QGraphicsView to determine what item is under the cursor, and for that
4906 reason, the implementation of this function should be as light-weight as
4907 possible.
4908
4909 By default, this function calls shape(), but you can reimplement it in a
4910 subclass to provide a (perhaps more efficient) implementation.
4911
4912 \sa shape(), boundingRect(), collidesWithPath()
4913*/
4914bool QGraphicsItem::contains(const QPointF &point) const
4915{
4916 return isClipped() ? clipPath().contains(pt: point) : shape().contains(pt: point);
4917}
4918
4919/*!
4920
4921 Returns \c true if this item collides with \a other; otherwise
4922 returns \c false.
4923
4924 The \a mode is applied to \a other, and the resulting shape or
4925 bounding rectangle is then compared to this item's shape. The
4926 default value for \a mode is Qt::IntersectsItemShape; \a other
4927 collides with this item if it either intersects, contains, or is
4928 contained by this item's shape (see Qt::ItemSelectionMode for
4929 details).
4930
4931 The default implementation is based on shape intersection, and it calls
4932 shape() on both items. Because the complexity of arbitrary shape-shape
4933 intersection grows with an order of magnitude when the shapes are complex,
4934 this operation can be noticeably time-consuming. You have the option of
4935 reimplementing this function in a subclass of QGraphicsItem to provide a
4936 custom algorithm. This allows you to make use of natural constraints in
4937 the shapes of your own items, in order to improve the performance of the
4938 collision detection. For instance, two untransformed perfectly circular
4939 items' collision can be determined very efficiently by comparing their
4940 positions and radii.
4941
4942 Keep in mind that when reimplementing this function and calling shape() or
4943 boundingRect() on \a other, the returned coordinates must be mapped to
4944 this item's coordinate system before any intersection can take place.
4945
4946 \sa contains(), shape()
4947*/
4948bool QGraphicsItem::collidesWithItem(const QGraphicsItem *other, Qt::ItemSelectionMode mode) const
4949{
4950 if (other == this)
4951 return true;
4952 if (!other)
4953 return false;
4954 // The items share the same clip if their closest clipper is the same, or
4955 // if one clips the other.
4956 bool clips = (d_ptr->ancestorFlags & QGraphicsItemPrivate::AncestorClipsChildren);
4957 bool otherClips = (other->d_ptr->ancestorFlags & QGraphicsItemPrivate::AncestorClipsChildren);
4958 if (clips || otherClips) {
4959 const QGraphicsItem *closestClipper = isAncestorOf(child: other) ? this : parentItem();
4960 while (closestClipper && !(closestClipper->flags() & ItemClipsChildrenToShape))
4961 closestClipper = closestClipper->parentItem();
4962 const QGraphicsItem *otherClosestClipper = other->isAncestorOf(child: this) ? other : other->parentItem();
4963 while (otherClosestClipper && !(otherClosestClipper->flags() & ItemClipsChildrenToShape))
4964 otherClosestClipper = otherClosestClipper->parentItem();
4965 if (closestClipper == otherClosestClipper) {
4966 d_ptr->localCollisionHack = 1;
4967 bool res = collidesWithPath(path: mapFromItem(item: other, path: other->shape()), mode);
4968 d_ptr->localCollisionHack = 0;
4969 return res;
4970 }
4971 }
4972
4973 QPainterPath otherShape = other->isClipped() ? other->clipPath() : other->shape();
4974 return collidesWithPath(path: mapFromItem(item: other, path: otherShape), mode);
4975}
4976
4977/*!
4978 Returns \c true if this item collides with \a path.
4979
4980 The collision is determined by \a mode. The default value for \a mode is
4981 Qt::IntersectsItemShape; \a path collides with this item if it either
4982 intersects, contains, or is contained by this item's shape.
4983
4984 Note that this function checks whether the item's shape or
4985 bounding rectangle (depending on \a mode) is contained within \a
4986 path, and not whether \a path is contained within the items shape
4987 or bounding rectangle.
4988
4989 \sa collidesWithItem(), contains(), shape()
4990*/
4991bool QGraphicsItem::collidesWithPath(const QPainterPath &path, Qt::ItemSelectionMode mode) const
4992{
4993 if (path.isEmpty()) {
4994 // No collision with empty paths.
4995 return false;
4996 }
4997
4998 QRectF rectA(boundingRect());
4999 _q_adjustRect(rect: &rectA);
5000 QRectF rectB(path.controlPointRect());
5001 _q_adjustRect(rect: &rectB);
5002 if (!rectA.intersects(r: rectB)) {
5003 // This we can determine efficiently. If the two rects neither
5004 // intersect nor contain each other, then the two items do not collide.
5005 return false;
5006 }
5007
5008 // For further testing, we need this item's shape or bounding rect.
5009 QPainterPath thisShape;
5010 if (mode == Qt::IntersectsItemShape || mode == Qt::ContainsItemShape)
5011 thisShape = (isClipped() && !d_ptr->localCollisionHack) ? clipPath() : shape();
5012 else
5013 thisShape.addRect(rect: rectA);
5014
5015 if (thisShape == QPainterPath()) {
5016 // Empty shape? No collision.
5017 return false;
5018 }
5019
5020 // Use QPainterPath boolean operations to determine the collision, O(N*logN).
5021 if (mode == Qt::IntersectsItemShape || mode == Qt::IntersectsItemBoundingRect)
5022 return path.intersects(p: thisShape);
5023 return path.contains(p: thisShape);
5024}
5025
5026/*!
5027 Returns a list of all items that collide with this item.
5028
5029 The way collisions are detected is determined by applying \a mode
5030 to items that are compared to this item, i.e., each item's shape
5031 or bounding rectangle is checked against this item's shape. The
5032 default value for \a mode is Qt::IntersectsItemShape.
5033
5034 \sa collidesWithItem()
5035*/
5036QList<QGraphicsItem *> QGraphicsItem::collidingItems(Qt::ItemSelectionMode mode) const
5037{
5038 if (d_ptr->scene)
5039 return d_ptr->scene->collidingItems(item: this, mode);
5040 return QList<QGraphicsItem *>();
5041}
5042
5043/*!
5044 \internal
5045
5046 Item obscurity helper function.
5047
5048 Returns \c true if the subrect \a rect of \a item's bounding rect is obscured
5049 by \a other (i.e., \a other's opaque area covers \a item's \a rect
5050 completely. \a other is assumed to already be "on top of" \a item
5051 wrt. stacking order.
5052*/
5053static bool qt_QGraphicsItem_isObscured(const QGraphicsItem *item,
5054 const QGraphicsItem *other,
5055 const QRectF &rect)
5056{
5057 return other->mapToItem(item, path: other->opaqueArea()).contains(rect);
5058}
5059
5060/*!
5061 \overload
5062 \since 4.3
5063
5064 Returns \c true if \a rect is completely obscured by the opaque shape of any
5065 of colliding items above it (i.e., with a higher Z value than this item).
5066
5067 \sa opaqueArea()
5068*/
5069bool QGraphicsItem::isObscured(const QRectF &rect) const
5070{
5071 Q_D(const QGraphicsItem);
5072 if (!d->scene)
5073 return false;
5074
5075 QRectF br = boundingRect();
5076 QRectF testRect = rect.isNull() ? br : rect;
5077
5078 const auto items = d->scene->items(polygon: mapToScene(rect: br), mode: Qt::IntersectsItemBoundingRect);
5079 for (QGraphicsItem *item : items) {
5080 if (item == this)
5081 break;
5082 if (qt_QGraphicsItem_isObscured(item: this, other: item, rect: testRect))
5083 return true;
5084 }
5085 return false;
5086}
5087
5088/*!
5089 \fn bool QGraphicsItem::isObscured(qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h) const
5090 \overload
5091 \since 4.3
5092
5093 This convenience function is equivalent to calling isObscured(QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h)).
5094*/
5095
5096/*!
5097 Returns \c true if this item's bounding rect is completely obscured by the
5098 opaque shape of \a item.
5099
5100 The base implementation maps \a item's opaqueArea() to this item's
5101 coordinate system, and then checks if this item's boundingRect() is fully
5102 contained within the mapped shape.
5103
5104 You can reimplement this function to provide a custom algorithm for
5105 determining whether this item is obscured by \a item.
5106
5107 \sa opaqueArea(), isObscured()
5108*/
5109bool QGraphicsItem::isObscuredBy(const QGraphicsItem *item) const
5110{
5111 if (!item)
5112 return false;
5113 return qt_closestItemFirst(item1: item, item2: this)
5114 && qt_QGraphicsItem_isObscured(item: this, other: item, rect: boundingRect());
5115}
5116
5117/*!
5118 This virtual function returns a shape representing the area where this
5119 item is opaque. An area is opaque if it is filled using an opaque brush or
5120 color (i.e., not transparent).
5121
5122 This function is used by isObscuredBy(), which is called by underlying
5123 items to determine if they are obscured by this item.
5124
5125 The default implementation returns an empty QPainterPath, indicating that
5126 this item is completely transparent and does not obscure any other items.
5127
5128 \sa isObscuredBy(), isObscured(), shape()
5129*/
5130QPainterPath QGraphicsItem::opaqueArea() const
5131{
5132 return QPainterPath();
5133}
5134
5135/*!
5136 \since 4.4
5137
5138 Returns the bounding region for this item. The coordinate space of the
5139 returned region depends on \a itemToDeviceTransform. If you pass an
5140 identity QTransform as a parameter, this function will return a local
5141 coordinate region.
5142
5143 The bounding region describes a coarse outline of the item's visual
5144 contents. Although it's expensive to calculate, it's also more precise
5145 than boundingRect(), and it can help to avoid unnecessary repainting when
5146 an item is updated. This is particularly efficient for thin items (e.g.,
5147 lines or simple polygons). You can tune the granularity for the bounding
5148 region by calling setBoundingRegionGranularity(). The default granularity
5149 is 0; in which the item's bounding region is the same as its bounding
5150 rect.
5151
5152 \a itemToDeviceTransform is the transformation from item coordinates to
5153 device coordinates. If you want this function to return a QRegion in scene
5154 coordinates, you can pass sceneTransform() as an argument.
5155
5156 \sa boundingRegionGranularity()
5157*/
5158QRegion QGraphicsItem::boundingRegion(const QTransform &itemToDeviceTransform) const
5159{
5160 // ### Ideally we would have a better way to generate this region,
5161 // preferably something in the lines of QPainterPath::toRegion(QTransform)
5162 // coupled with a way to generate a painter path from a set of painter
5163 // operations (e.g., QPicture::toPainterPath() or so). The current
5164 // approach generates a bitmap with the size of the item's bounding rect
5165 // in device coordinates, scaled by b.r.granularity, then paints the item
5166 // into the bitmap, converts the result to a QRegion and scales the region
5167 // back to device space with inverse granularity.
5168 qreal granularity = boundingRegionGranularity();
5169 QRect deviceRect = itemToDeviceTransform.mapRect(boundingRect()).toRect();
5170 _q_adjustRect(rect: &deviceRect);
5171 if (granularity == 0.0)
5172 return QRegion(deviceRect);
5173
5174 int pad = 1;
5175 QSize bitmapSize(qMax(a: 1, b: int(deviceRect.width() * granularity) + pad * 2),
5176 qMax(a: 1, b: int(deviceRect.height() * granularity) + pad * 2));
5177 QImage mask(bitmapSize, QImage::Format_ARGB32_Premultiplied);
5178 mask.fill(pixel: 0);
5179 QPainter p(&mask);
5180 p.setRenderHints(hints: QPainter::Antialiasing);
5181
5182 // Transform painter (### this code is from QGraphicsScene::drawItemHelper
5183 // and doesn't work properly with perspective transformations).
5184 QPointF viewOrigo = itemToDeviceTransform.map(p: QPointF(0, 0));
5185 QPointF offset = viewOrigo - deviceRect.topLeft();
5186 p.scale(sx: granularity, sy: granularity);
5187 p.translate(offset);
5188 p.translate(dx: pad, dy: pad);
5189 p.setWorldTransform(matrix: itemToDeviceTransform, combine: true);
5190 p.translate(offset: itemToDeviceTransform.inverted().map(p: QPointF(0, 0)));
5191
5192 // Render
5193 QStyleOptionGraphicsItem option;
5194 const_cast<QGraphicsItem *>(this)->paint(painter: &p, option: &option, widget: nullptr);
5195 p.end();
5196
5197 // Transform QRegion back to device space
5198 QTransform unscale = QTransform::fromScale(dx: 1 / granularity, dy: 1 / granularity);
5199 QRegion r;
5200 QBitmap colorMask = QBitmap::fromImage(image: mask.createMaskFromColor(color: 0));
5201 for (const QRect &rect : QRegion(colorMask)) {
5202 QRect xrect = unscale.mapRect(rect).translated(p: deviceRect.topLeft() - QPoint(pad, pad));
5203 r += xrect.adjusted(xp1: -1, yp1: -1, xp2: 1, yp2: 1) & deviceRect;
5204 }
5205 return r;
5206}
5207
5208/*!
5209 \since 4.4
5210
5211 Returns the item's bounding region granularity; a value between and
5212 including 0 and 1. The default value is 0 (i.e., the lowest granularity,
5213 where the bounding region corresponds to the item's bounding rectangle).
5214
5215\omit
5216### NOTE
5217\endomit
5218
5219 \sa setBoundingRegionGranularity()
5220*/
5221qreal QGraphicsItem::boundingRegionGranularity() const
5222{
5223 return d_ptr->hasBoundingRegionGranularity
5224 ? qvariant_cast<qreal>(v: d_ptr->extra(type: QGraphicsItemPrivate::ExtraBoundingRegionGranularity))
5225 : 0;
5226}
5227
5228/*!
5229 \since 4.4
5230 Sets the bounding region granularity to \a granularity; a value between
5231 and including 0 and 1. The default value is 0 (i.e., the lowest
5232 granularity, where the bounding region corresponds to the item's bounding
5233 rectangle).
5234
5235 The granularity is used by boundingRegion() to calculate how fine the
5236 bounding region of the item should be. The highest achievable granularity
5237 is 1, where boundingRegion() will return the finest outline possible for
5238 the respective device (e.g., for a QGraphicsView viewport, this gives you
5239 a pixel-perfect bounding region). The lowest possible granularity is
5240 0. The value of \a granularity describes the ratio between device
5241 resolution and the resolution of the bounding region (e.g., a value of
5242 0.25 will provide a region where each chunk corresponds to 4x4 device
5243 units / pixels).
5244
5245 \sa boundingRegionGranularity()
5246*/
5247void QGraphicsItem::setBoundingRegionGranularity(qreal granularity)
5248{
5249 if (granularity < 0.0 || granularity > 1.0) {
5250 qWarning(msg: "QGraphicsItem::setBoundingRegionGranularity: invalid granularity %g", granularity);
5251 return;
5252 }
5253 if (granularity == 0.0) {
5254 d_ptr->unsetExtra(type: QGraphicsItemPrivate::ExtraBoundingRegionGranularity);
5255 d_ptr->hasBoundingRegionGranularity = 0;
5256 return;
5257 }
5258 d_ptr->hasBoundingRegionGranularity = 1;
5259 d_ptr->setExtra(type: QGraphicsItemPrivate::ExtraBoundingRegionGranularity,
5260 value: QVariant::fromValue<qreal>(value: granularity));
5261}
5262
5263/*!
5264 \fn virtual void QGraphicsItem::paint(QPainter *painter, const
5265 QStyleOptionGraphicsItem *option, QWidget *widget = nullptr) = 0
5266
5267 This function, which is usually called by QGraphicsView, paints the
5268 contents of an item in local coordinates.
5269
5270 Reimplement this function in a QGraphicsItem subclass to provide the
5271 item's painting implementation, using \a painter. The \a option parameter
5272 provides style options for the item, such as its state, exposed area and
5273 its level-of-detail hints. The \a widget argument is optional. If
5274 provided, it points to the widget that is being painted on; otherwise, it
5275 is 0. For cached painting, \a widget is always 0.
5276
5277 \snippet code/src_gui_graphicsview_qgraphicsitem.cpp 10
5278
5279 The painter's pen is 0-width by default, and its pen is initialized to the
5280 QPalette::Text brush from the paint device's palette. The brush is
5281 initialized to QPalette::Window.
5282
5283 Make sure to constrain all painting inside the boundaries of
5284 boundingRect() to avoid rendering artifacts (as QGraphicsView does not
5285 clip the painter for you). In particular, when QPainter renders the
5286 outline of a shape using an assigned QPen, half of the outline will be
5287 drawn outside, and half inside, the shape you're rendering (e.g., with a
5288 pen width of 2 units, you must draw outlines 1 unit inside
5289 boundingRect()). QGraphicsItem does not support use of cosmetic pens with
5290 a non-zero width.
5291
5292 All painting is done in local coordinates.
5293
5294 \note It is mandatory that an item will always redraw itself in the exact
5295 same way, unless update() was called; otherwise visual artifacts may
5296 occur. In other words, two subsequent calls to paint() must always produce
5297 the same output, unless update() was called between them.
5298
5299 \note Enabling caching for an item does not guarantee that paint()
5300 will be invoked only once by the Graphics View framework,
5301 even without any explicit call to update(). See the documentation of
5302 setCacheMode() for more details.
5303
5304 \sa setCacheMode(), QPen::width(), {Item Coordinates}, ItemUsesExtendedStyleOption
5305*/
5306
5307/*!
5308 \internal
5309 Returns \c true if we can discard an update request; otherwise false.
5310*/
5311bool QGraphicsItemPrivate::discardUpdateRequest(bool ignoreVisibleBit, bool ignoreDirtyBit,
5312 bool ignoreOpacity) const
5313{
5314 // No scene, or if the scene is updating everything, means we have nothing
5315 // to do. The only exception is if the scene tracks the growing scene rect.
5316 return !scene
5317 || (!visible && !ignoreVisibleBit && !this->ignoreVisible)
5318 || (!ignoreDirtyBit && fullUpdatePending)
5319 || (!ignoreOpacity && !this->ignoreOpacity && childrenCombineOpacity() && isFullyTransparent());
5320}
5321
5322/*!
5323 \internal
5324*/
5325int QGraphicsItemPrivate::depth() const
5326{
5327 if (itemDepth == -1)
5328 const_cast<QGraphicsItemPrivate *>(this)->resolveDepth();
5329
5330 return itemDepth;
5331}
5332
5333/*!
5334 \internal
5335*/
5336#if QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
5337void QGraphicsItemPrivate::invalidateParentGraphicsEffectsRecursively()
5338{
5339 QGraphicsItemPrivate *itemPrivate = this;
5340 do {
5341 if (itemPrivate->graphicsEffect) {
5342 itemPrivate->notifyInvalidated = 1;
5343
5344 if (!itemPrivate->updateDueToGraphicsEffect)
5345 static_cast<QGraphicsItemEffectSourcePrivate *>(itemPrivate->graphicsEffect->d_func()->source->d_func())->invalidateCache();
5346 }
5347 } while ((itemPrivate = itemPrivate->parent ? itemPrivate->parent->d_ptr.data() : nullptr));
5348}
5349
5350void QGraphicsItemPrivate::invalidateChildGraphicsEffectsRecursively(QGraphicsItemPrivate::InvalidateReason reason)
5351{
5352 if (!mayHaveChildWithGraphicsEffect)
5353 return;
5354
5355 for (int i = 0; i < children.size(); ++i) {
5356 QGraphicsItemPrivate *childPrivate = children.at(i)->d_ptr.data();
5357 if (reason == OpacityChanged && (childPrivate->flags & QGraphicsItem::ItemIgnoresParentOpacity))
5358 continue;
5359 if (childPrivate->graphicsEffect) {
5360 childPrivate->notifyInvalidated = 1;
5361 static_cast<QGraphicsItemEffectSourcePrivate *>(childPrivate->graphicsEffect->d_func()->source->d_func())->invalidateCache();
5362 }
5363
5364 childPrivate->invalidateChildGraphicsEffectsRecursively(reason);
5365 }
5366}
5367#endif // QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
5368
5369/*!
5370 \internal
5371*/
5372void QGraphicsItemPrivate::invalidateDepthRecursively()
5373{
5374 if (itemDepth == -1)
5375 return;
5376
5377 itemDepth = -1;
5378 for (int i = 0; i < children.size(); ++i)
5379 children.at(i)->d_ptr->invalidateDepthRecursively();
5380}
5381
5382/*!
5383 \internal
5384
5385 Resolves the stacking depth of this object and all its ancestors.
5386*/
5387void QGraphicsItemPrivate::resolveDepth()
5388{
5389 if (!parent)
5390 itemDepth = 0;
5391 else {
5392 if (parent->d_ptr->itemDepth == -1)
5393 parent->d_ptr->resolveDepth();
5394 itemDepth = parent->d_ptr->itemDepth + 1;
5395 }
5396}
5397
5398/*!
5399 \internal
5400
5401 ### This function is almost identical to
5402 QGraphicsScenePrivate::registerTopLevelItem().
5403*/
5404void QGraphicsItemPrivate::addChild(QGraphicsItem *child)
5405{
5406 // Remove all holes from the sibling index list. Now the max index
5407 // number is equal to the size of the children list.
5408 ensureSequentialSiblingIndex();
5409 needSortChildren = 1; // ### maybe 0
5410 child->d_ptr->siblingIndex = children.size();
5411 children.append(t: child);
5412 if (isObject)
5413 emit static_cast<QGraphicsObject *>(q_ptr)->childrenChanged();
5414}
5415
5416/*!
5417 \internal
5418
5419 ### This function is almost identical to
5420 QGraphicsScenePrivate::unregisterTopLevelItem().
5421*/
5422void QGraphicsItemPrivate::removeChild(QGraphicsItem *child)
5423{
5424 // When removing elements in the middle of the children list,
5425 // there will be a "gap" in the list of sibling indexes (0,1,3,4).
5426 if (!holesInSiblingIndex)
5427 holesInSiblingIndex = child->d_ptr->siblingIndex != children.size() - 1;
5428 if (sequentialOrdering && !holesInSiblingIndex)
5429 children.removeAt(i: child->d_ptr->siblingIndex);
5430 else
5431 children.removeOne(t: child);
5432 // NB! Do not use children.removeAt(child->d_ptr->siblingIndex) because
5433 // the child is not guaranteed to be at the index after the list is sorted.
5434 // (see ensureSortedChildren()).
5435 child->d_ptr->siblingIndex = -1;
5436 if (isObject)
5437 emit static_cast<QGraphicsObject *>(q_ptr)->childrenChanged();
5438}
5439
5440/*!
5441 \internal
5442*/
5443QGraphicsItemCache *QGraphicsItemPrivate::maybeExtraItemCache() const
5444{
5445 return (QGraphicsItemCache *)qvariant_cast<void *>(v: extra(type: ExtraCacheData));
5446}
5447
5448/*!
5449 \internal
5450*/
5451QGraphicsItemCache *QGraphicsItemPrivate::extraItemCache() const
5452{
5453 QGraphicsItemCache *c = (QGraphicsItemCache *)qvariant_cast<void *>(v: extra(type: ExtraCacheData));
5454 if (!c) {
5455 QGraphicsItemPrivate *that = const_cast<QGraphicsItemPrivate *>(this);
5456 c = new QGraphicsItemCache;
5457 that->setExtra(type: ExtraCacheData, value: QVariant::fromValue<void *>(value: c));
5458 }
5459 return c;
5460}
5461
5462/*!
5463 \internal
5464*/
5465void QGraphicsItemPrivate::removeExtraItemCache()
5466{
5467 QGraphicsItemCache *c = (QGraphicsItemCache *)qvariant_cast<void *>(v: extra(type: ExtraCacheData));
5468 if (c) {
5469 c->purge();
5470 delete c;
5471 }
5472 unsetExtra(type: ExtraCacheData);
5473}
5474
5475void QGraphicsItemPrivate::updatePaintedViewBoundingRects(bool updateChildren)
5476{
5477 if (!scene)
5478 return;
5479
5480 for (int i = 0; i < scene->d_func()->views.size(); ++i) {
5481 QGraphicsViewPrivate *viewPrivate = scene->d_func()->views.at(i)->d_func();
5482 QRect rect = paintedViewBoundingRects.value(key: viewPrivate->viewport);
5483 rect.translate(p: viewPrivate->dirtyScrollOffset);
5484 viewPrivate->updateRect(rect);
5485 }
5486
5487 if (updateChildren) {
5488 for (int i = 0; i < children.size(); ++i)
5489 children.at(i)->d_ptr->updatePaintedViewBoundingRects(updateChildren: true);
5490 }
5491}
5492
5493// Traverses all the ancestors up to the top-level and updates the pointer to
5494// always point to the top-most item that has a dirty scene transform.
5495// It then backtracks to the top-most dirty item and start calculating the
5496// scene transform by combining the item's transform (+pos) with the parent's
5497// cached scene transform (which we at this point know for sure is valid).
5498void QGraphicsItemPrivate::ensureSceneTransformRecursive(QGraphicsItem **topMostDirtyItem)
5499{
5500 Q_ASSERT(topMostDirtyItem);
5501
5502 if (dirtySceneTransform)
5503 *topMostDirtyItem = q_ptr;
5504
5505 if (parent)
5506 parent->d_ptr->ensureSceneTransformRecursive(topMostDirtyItem);
5507
5508 if (*topMostDirtyItem == q_ptr) {
5509 if (!dirtySceneTransform)
5510 return; // OK, neither my ancestors nor I have dirty scene transforms.
5511 *topMostDirtyItem = nullptr;
5512 } else if (*topMostDirtyItem) {
5513 return; // Continue backtrack.
5514 }
5515
5516 // This item and all its descendants have dirty scene transforms.
5517 // We're about to validate this item's scene transform, so we have to
5518 // invalidate all the children; otherwise there's no way for the descendants
5519 // to detect that the ancestor has changed.
5520 invalidateChildrenSceneTransform();
5521
5522 // COMBINE my transform with the parent's scene transform.
5523 updateSceneTransformFromParent();
5524 Q_ASSERT(!dirtySceneTransform);
5525}
5526
5527/*!
5528 \internal
5529*/
5530void QGraphicsItemPrivate::setSubFocus(QGraphicsItem *rootItem, QGraphicsItem *stopItem)
5531{
5532 // Update focus child chain. Stop at panels, or if this item
5533 // is hidden, stop at the first item with a visible parent.
5534 QGraphicsItem *parent = rootItem ? rootItem : q_ptr;
5535 if (parent->panel() != q_ptr->panel())
5536 return;
5537
5538 do {
5539 // Clear any existing ancestor's subFocusItem.
5540 if (parent != q_ptr && parent->d_ptr->subFocusItem) {
5541 if (parent->d_ptr->subFocusItem == q_ptr)
5542 break;
5543 parent->d_ptr->subFocusItem->d_ptr->clearSubFocus(rootItem: nullptr, stopItem);
5544 }
5545 parent->d_ptr->subFocusItem = q_ptr;
5546 parent->d_ptr->subFocusItemChange();
5547 } while (!parent->isPanel() && (parent = parent->d_ptr->parent) && (visible || !parent->d_ptr->visible));
5548
5549 if (scene && !scene->isActive()) {
5550 scene->d_func()->passiveFocusItem = subFocusItem;
5551 scene->d_func()->lastFocusItem = subFocusItem;
5552 }
5553}
5554
5555/*!
5556 \internal
5557*/
5558void QGraphicsItemPrivate::clearSubFocus(QGraphicsItem *rootItem, QGraphicsItem *stopItem)
5559{
5560 // Reset sub focus chain.
5561 QGraphicsItem *parent = rootItem ? rootItem : q_ptr;
5562 do {
5563 if (parent->d_ptr->subFocusItem != q_ptr)
5564 break;
5565 parent->d_ptr->subFocusItem = nullptr;
5566 if (parent != stopItem && !parent->isAncestorOf(child: stopItem))
5567 parent->d_ptr->subFocusItemChange();
5568 } while (!parent->isPanel() && (parent = parent->d_ptr->parent));
5569}
5570
5571/*!
5572 \internal
5573
5574 Sets the focusProxy pointer to \nullptr for all items that have this item as their
5575 focusProxy.
5576*/
5577void QGraphicsItemPrivate::resetFocusProxy()
5578{
5579 for (int i = 0; i < focusProxyRefs.size(); ++i)
5580 *focusProxyRefs.at(i) = nullptr;
5581 focusProxyRefs.clear();
5582}
5583
5584/*!
5585 \internal
5586
5587 Subclasses can reimplement this function to be notified when subFocusItem
5588 changes.
5589*/
5590void QGraphicsItemPrivate::subFocusItemChange()
5591{
5592}
5593
5594/*!
5595 \internal
5596
5597 Subclasses can reimplement this function to be notified when an item
5598 becomes a focusScopeItem (or is no longer a focusScopeItem).
5599*/
5600void QGraphicsItemPrivate::focusScopeItemChange(bool isSubFocusItem)
5601{
5602 Q_UNUSED(isSubFocusItem);
5603}
5604
5605/*!
5606 \internal
5607
5608 Subclasses can reimplement this function to be notified when its
5609 siblingIndex order is changed.
5610*/
5611void QGraphicsItemPrivate::siblingOrderChange()
5612{
5613}
5614
5615/*!
5616 \internal
5617
5618 Tells us if it is a proxy widget
5619*/
5620bool QGraphicsItemPrivate::isProxyWidget() const
5621{
5622 return false;
5623}
5624
5625/*!
5626 Schedules a redraw of the area covered by \a rect in this item. You can
5627 call this function whenever your item needs to be redrawn, such as if it
5628 changes appearance or size.
5629
5630 This function does not cause an immediate paint; instead it schedules a
5631 paint request that is processed by QGraphicsView after control reaches the
5632 event loop. The item will only be redrawn if it is visible in any
5633 associated view.
5634
5635 As a side effect of the item being repainted, other items that overlap the
5636 area \a rect may also be repainted.
5637
5638 If the item is invisible (i.e., isVisible() returns \c false), this function
5639 does nothing.
5640
5641 \sa paint(), boundingRect()
5642*/
5643void QGraphicsItem::update(const QRectF &rect)
5644{
5645 if (rect.isEmpty() && !rect.isNull())
5646 return;
5647
5648 // Make sure we notify effects about invalidated source.
5649#if QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
5650 d_ptr->invalidateParentGraphicsEffectsRecursively();
5651#endif // QT_CONFIG(graphicseffect)
5652
5653 if (CacheMode(d_ptr->cacheMode) != NoCache) {
5654 // Invalidate cache.
5655 QGraphicsItemCache *cache = d_ptr->extraItemCache();
5656 if (!cache->allExposed) {
5657 if (rect.isNull()) {
5658 cache->allExposed = true;
5659 cache->exposed.clear();
5660 } else {
5661 cache->exposed.append(t: rect);
5662 }
5663 }
5664 // Only invalidate cache; item is already dirty.
5665 if (d_ptr->fullUpdatePending)
5666 return;
5667 }
5668
5669 if (d_ptr->scene)
5670 d_ptr->scene->d_func()->markDirty(item: this, rect);
5671}
5672
5673/*!
5674 \since 4.4
5675 Scrolls the contents of \a rect by \a dx, \a dy. If \a rect is a null rect
5676 (the default), the item's bounding rect is scrolled.
5677
5678 Scrolling provides a fast alternative to simply redrawing when the
5679 contents of the item (or parts of the item) are shifted vertically or
5680 horizontally. Depending on the current transformation and the capabilities
5681 of the paint device (i.e., the viewport), this operation may consist of
5682 simply moving pixels from one location to another using memmove(). In most
5683 cases this is faster than rerendering the entire area.
5684
5685 After scrolling, the item will issue an update for the newly exposed
5686 areas. If scrolling is not supported (e.g., you are rendering to an OpenGL
5687 viewport, which does not benefit from scroll optimizations), this function
5688 is equivalent to calling update(\a rect).
5689
5690 \b{Note:} Scrolling is only supported when QGraphicsItem::ItemCoordinateCache
5691 is enabled; in all other cases calling this function is equivalent to calling
5692 update(\a rect). If you for sure know that the item is opaque and not overlapped
5693 by other items, you can map the \a rect to viewport coordinates and scroll the
5694 viewport.
5695
5696 \snippet code/src_gui_graphicsview_qgraphicsitem.cpp 19
5697
5698 \sa boundingRect()
5699*/
5700void QGraphicsItem::scroll(qreal dx, qreal dy, const QRectF &rect)
5701{
5702 Q_D(QGraphicsItem);
5703 if (dx == 0.0 && dy == 0.0)
5704 return;
5705 if (!d->scene)
5706 return;
5707
5708 // Accelerated scrolling means moving pixels from one location to another
5709 // and only redraw the newly exposed area. The following requirements must
5710 // be fulfilled in order to do that:
5711 //
5712 // 1) Item is opaque.
5713 // 2) Item is not overlapped by other items.
5714 //
5715 // There's (yet) no way to detect whether an item is opaque or not, which means
5716 // we cannot do accelerated scrolling unless the cache is enabled. In case of using
5717 // DeviceCoordinate cache we also have to take the device transform into account in
5718 // order to determine whether we can do accelerated scrolling or not. That's left out
5719 // for simplicity here, but it is definitely something we can consider in the future
5720 // as a performance improvement.
5721 if (d->cacheMode != QGraphicsItem::ItemCoordinateCache
5722 || !qFuzzyIsNull(d: dx - int(dx)) || !qFuzzyIsNull(d: dy - int(dy))) {
5723 update(rect);
5724 return;
5725 }
5726
5727 QGraphicsItemCache *cache = d->extraItemCache();
5728 if (cache->allExposed || cache->fixedSize.isValid()) {
5729 // Cache is either invalidated or item is scaled (see QGraphicsItem::setCacheMode).
5730 update(rect);
5731 return;
5732 }
5733
5734 // Find pixmap in cache.
5735 QPixmap cachedPixmap;
5736 if (!QPixmapCache::find(key: cache->key, pixmap: &cachedPixmap)) {
5737 update(rect);
5738 return;
5739 }
5740
5741 QRect scrollRect = (rect.isNull() ? boundingRect() : rect).toAlignedRect();
5742 if (!scrollRect.intersects(r: cache->boundingRect))
5743 return; // Nothing to scroll.
5744
5745 // Remove from cache to avoid deep copy when modifying.
5746 QPixmapCache::remove(key: cache->key);
5747
5748 QRegion exposed;
5749 cachedPixmap.scroll(dx, dy, rect: scrollRect.translated(p: -cache->boundingRect.topLeft()), exposed: &exposed);
5750
5751 // Reinsert into cache.
5752 cache->key = QPixmapCache::insert(pixmap: cachedPixmap);
5753
5754 // Translate the existing expose.
5755 for (int i = 0; i < cache->exposed.size(); ++i) {
5756 QRectF &e = cache->exposed[i];
5757 if (!rect.isNull() && !e.intersects(r: rect))
5758 continue;
5759 e.translate(dx, dy);
5760 }
5761
5762 // Append newly exposed areas. Note that the exposed region is currently
5763 // in pixmap coordinates, so we have to translate it to item coordinates.
5764 exposed.translate(p: cache->boundingRect.topLeft());
5765 for (const QRect &exposedRect : exposed)
5766 cache->exposed += exposedRect;
5767
5768 // Trigger update. This will redraw the newly exposed area and make sure
5769 // the pixmap is re-blitted in case there are overlapping items.
5770 d->scene->d_func()->markDirty(item: this, rect);
5771}
5772
5773/*!
5774 \fn void QGraphicsItem::update(qreal x, qreal y, qreal width, qreal height)
5775 \overload
5776
5777 This convenience function is equivalent to calling update(QRectF(\a x, \a
5778 y, \a width, \a height)).
5779*/
5780
5781/*!
5782 Maps the point \a point, which is in this item's coordinate system, to \a
5783 item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped coordinate.
5784
5785 If \a item is \nullptr, this function returns the same as mapToScene().
5786
5787 \sa itemTransform(), mapToParent(), mapToScene(), transform(), mapFromItem(), {The Graphics
5788 View Coordinate System}
5789*/
5790QPointF QGraphicsItem::mapToItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, const QPointF &point) const
5791{
5792 if (item)
5793 return itemTransform(other: item).map(p: point);
5794 return mapToScene(point);
5795}
5796
5797/*!
5798 \fn QPointF QGraphicsItem::mapToItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, qreal x, qreal y) const
5799 \overload
5800
5801 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapToItem(\a item,
5802 QPointF(\a x, \a y)).
5803*/
5804
5805/*!
5806 Maps the point \a point, which is in this item's coordinate system, to its
5807 parent's coordinate system, and returns the mapped coordinate. If the item
5808 has no parent, \a point will be mapped to the scene's coordinate system.
5809
5810 \sa mapToItem(), mapToScene(), transform(), mapFromParent(), {The Graphics
5811 View Coordinate System}
5812*/
5813QPointF QGraphicsItem::mapToParent(const QPointF &point) const
5814{
5815 // COMBINE
5816 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
5817 return point + d_ptr->pos;
5818 return d_ptr->transformToParent().map(p: point);
5819}
5820
5821/*!
5822 \fn QPointF QGraphicsItem::mapToParent(qreal x, qreal y) const
5823 \overload
5824
5825 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapToParent(QPointF(\a
5826 x, \a y)).
5827*/
5828
5829/*!
5830 Maps the point \a point, which is in this item's coordinate system, to the
5831 scene's coordinate system, and returns the mapped coordinate.
5832
5833 \sa mapToItem(), mapToParent(), transform(), mapFromScene(), {The Graphics
5834 View Coordinate System}
5835*/
5836QPointF QGraphicsItem::mapToScene(const QPointF &point) const
5837{
5838 if (d_ptr->hasTranslateOnlySceneTransform())
5839 return QPointF(point.x() + d_ptr->sceneTransform.dx(), point.y() + d_ptr->sceneTransform.dy());
5840 return d_ptr->sceneTransform.map(p: point);
5841}
5842
5843/*!
5844 \fn QPointF QGraphicsItem::mapToScene(qreal x, qreal y) const
5845 \overload
5846
5847 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapToScene(QPointF(\a
5848 x, \a y)).
5849*/
5850
5851/*!
5852 Maps the rectangle \a rect, which is in this item's coordinate system, to
5853 \a item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped rectangle as a polygon.
5854
5855 If \a item is \nullptr, this function returns the same as mapToScene().
5856
5857 \sa itemTransform(), mapToParent(), mapToScene(), mapFromItem(), {The
5858 Graphics View Coordinate System}
5859*/
5860QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapToItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, const QRectF &rect) const
5861{
5862 if (item)
5863 return itemTransform(other: item).map(a: rect);
5864 return mapToScene(rect);
5865}
5866
5867/*!
5868 \fn QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapToItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h) const
5869 \since 4.3
5870
5871 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapToItem(item, QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h)).
5872*/
5873
5874/*!
5875 Maps the rectangle \a rect, which is in this item's coordinate system, to
5876 its parent's coordinate system, and returns the mapped rectangle as a
5877 polygon. If the item has no parent, \a rect will be mapped to the scene's
5878 coordinate system.
5879
5880 \sa mapToScene(), mapToItem(), mapFromParent(), {The Graphics View
5881 Coordinate System}
5882*/
5883QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapToParent(const QRectF &rect) const
5884{
5885 // COMBINE
5886 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
5887 return rect.translated(p: d_ptr->pos);
5888 return d_ptr->transformToParent().map(a: rect);
5889}
5890
5891/*!
5892 \fn QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapToParent(qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h) const
5893 \since 4.3
5894
5895 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapToParent(QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h)).
5896*/
5897
5898/*!
5899 Maps the rectangle \a rect, which is in this item's coordinate system, to
5900 the scene's coordinate system, and returns the mapped rectangle as a polygon.
5901
5902 \sa mapToParent(), mapToItem(), mapFromScene(), {The Graphics View
5903 Coordinate System}
5904*/
5905QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapToScene(const QRectF &rect) const
5906{
5907 if (d_ptr->hasTranslateOnlySceneTransform())
5908 return rect.translated(dx: d_ptr->sceneTransform.dx(), dy: d_ptr->sceneTransform.dy());
5909 return d_ptr->sceneTransform.map(a: rect);
5910}
5911
5912/*!
5913 \fn QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapToScene(qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h) const
5914 \since 4.3
5915
5916 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapToScene(QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h)).
5917*/
5918
5919/*!
5920 \since 4.5
5921
5922 Maps the rectangle \a rect, which is in this item's coordinate system, to
5923 \a item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped rectangle as a new
5924 rectangle (i.e., the bounding rectangle of the resulting polygon).
5925
5926 If \a item is \nullptr, this function returns the same as mapRectToScene().
5927
5928 \sa itemTransform(), mapToParent(), mapToScene(), mapFromItem(), {The
5929 Graphics View Coordinate System}
5930*/
5931QRectF QGraphicsItem::mapRectToItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, const QRectF &rect) const
5932{
5933 if (item)
5934 return itemTransform(other: item).mapRect(rect);
5935 return mapRectToScene(rect);
5936}
5937
5938/*!
5939 \fn QRectF QGraphicsItem::mapRectToItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h) const
5940 \since 4.5
5941
5942 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapRectToItem(item, QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h)).
5943*/
5944
5945/*!
5946 \since 4.5
5947
5948 Maps the rectangle \a rect, which is in this item's coordinate system, to
5949 its parent's coordinate system, and returns the mapped rectangle as a new
5950 rectangle (i.e., the bounding rectangle of the resulting polygon).
5951
5952 \sa itemTransform(), mapToParent(), mapToScene(), mapFromItem(), {The
5953 Graphics View Coordinate System}
5954*/
5955QRectF QGraphicsItem::mapRectToParent(const QRectF &rect) const
5956{
5957 // COMBINE
5958 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
5959 return rect.translated(p: d_ptr->pos);
5960 return d_ptr->transformToParent().mapRect(rect);
5961}
5962
5963/*!
5964 \fn QRectF QGraphicsItem::mapRectToParent(qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h) const
5965 \since 4.5
5966
5967 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapRectToParent(QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h)).
5968*/
5969
5970/*!
5971 \since 4.5
5972
5973 Maps the rectangle \a rect, which is in this item's coordinate system, to
5974 the scene coordinate system, and returns the mapped rectangle as a new
5975 rectangle (i.e., the bounding rectangle of the resulting polygon).
5976
5977 \sa itemTransform(), mapToParent(), mapToScene(), mapFromItem(), {The
5978 Graphics View Coordinate System}
5979*/
5980QRectF QGraphicsItem::mapRectToScene(const QRectF &rect) const
5981{
5982 if (d_ptr->hasTranslateOnlySceneTransform())
5983 return rect.translated(dx: d_ptr->sceneTransform.dx(), dy: d_ptr->sceneTransform.dy());
5984 return d_ptr->sceneTransform.mapRect(rect);
5985}
5986
5987/*!
5988 \fn QRectF QGraphicsItem::mapRectToScene(qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h) const
5989 \since 4.5
5990
5991 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapRectToScene(QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h)).
5992*/
5993
5994/*!
5995 \since 4.5
5996
5997 Maps the rectangle \a rect, which is in \a item's coordinate system, to
5998 this item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped rectangle as a new
5999 rectangle (i.e., the bounding rectangle of the resulting polygon).
6000
6001 If \a item is \nullptr, this function returns the same as mapRectFromScene().
6002
6003 \sa itemTransform(), mapToParent(), mapToScene(), mapFromItem(), {The
6004 Graphics View Coordinate System}
6005*/
6006QRectF QGraphicsItem::mapRectFromItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, const QRectF &rect) const
6007{
6008 if (item)
6009 return item->itemTransform(other: this).mapRect(rect);
6010 return mapRectFromScene(rect);
6011}
6012
6013/*!
6014 \fn QRectF QGraphicsItem::mapRectFromItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h) const
6015 \since 4.5
6016
6017 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapRectFromItem(item, QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h)).
6018*/
6019
6020/*!
6021 \since 4.5
6022
6023 Maps the rectangle \a rect, which is in this item's parent's coordinate
6024 system, to this item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped rectangle
6025 as a new rectangle (i.e., the bounding rectangle of the resulting
6026 polygon).
6027
6028 \sa itemTransform(), mapToParent(), mapToScene(), mapFromItem(), {The
6029 Graphics View Coordinate System}
6030*/
6031QRectF QGraphicsItem::mapRectFromParent(const QRectF &rect) const
6032{
6033 // COMBINE
6034 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
6035 return rect.translated(p: -d_ptr->pos);
6036 return d_ptr->transformToParent().inverted().mapRect(rect);
6037}
6038
6039/*!
6040 \fn QRectF QGraphicsItem::mapRectFromParent(qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h) const
6041 \since 4.5
6042
6043 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapRectFromParent(QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h)).
6044*/
6045
6046/*!
6047 \since 4.5
6048
6049 Maps the rectangle \a rect, which is in scene coordinates, to this item's
6050 coordinate system, and returns the mapped rectangle as a new rectangle
6051 (i.e., the bounding rectangle of the resulting polygon).
6052
6053 \sa itemTransform(), mapToParent(), mapToScene(), mapFromItem(), {The
6054 Graphics View Coordinate System}
6055*/
6056QRectF QGraphicsItem::mapRectFromScene(const QRectF &rect) const
6057{
6058 if (d_ptr->hasTranslateOnlySceneTransform())
6059 return rect.translated(dx: -d_ptr->sceneTransform.dx(), dy: -d_ptr->sceneTransform.dy());
6060 return d_ptr->sceneTransform.inverted().mapRect(rect);
6061}
6062
6063/*!
6064 \fn QRectF QGraphicsItem::mapRectFromScene(qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h) const
6065 \since 4.5
6066
6067 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapRectFromScene(QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h)).
6068*/
6069
6070/*!
6071 Maps the polygon \a polygon, which is in this item's coordinate system, to
6072 \a item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped polygon.
6073
6074 If \a item is \nullptr, this function returns the same as mapToScene().
6075
6076 \sa itemTransform(), mapToParent(), mapToScene(), mapFromItem(), {The
6077 Graphics View Coordinate System}
6078*/
6079QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapToItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, const QPolygonF &polygon) const
6080{
6081 if (item)
6082 return itemTransform(other: item).map(a: polygon);
6083 return mapToScene(polygon);
6084}
6085
6086/*!
6087 Maps the polygon \a polygon, which is in this item's coordinate system, to
6088 its parent's coordinate system, and returns the mapped polygon. If the
6089 item has no parent, \a polygon will be mapped to the scene's coordinate
6090 system.
6091
6092 \sa mapToScene(), mapToItem(), mapFromParent(), {The Graphics View
6093 Coordinate System}
6094*/
6095QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapToParent(const QPolygonF &polygon) const
6096{
6097 // COMBINE
6098 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
6099 return polygon.translated(offset: d_ptr->pos);
6100 return d_ptr->transformToParent().map(a: polygon);
6101}
6102
6103/*!
6104 Maps the polygon \a polygon, which is in this item's coordinate system, to
6105 the scene's coordinate system, and returns the mapped polygon.
6106
6107 \sa mapToParent(), mapToItem(), mapFromScene(), {The Graphics View
6108 Coordinate System}
6109*/
6110QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapToScene(const QPolygonF &polygon) const
6111{
6112 if (d_ptr->hasTranslateOnlySceneTransform())
6113 return polygon.translated(dx: d_ptr->sceneTransform.dx(), dy: d_ptr->sceneTransform.dy());
6114 return d_ptr->sceneTransform.map(a: polygon);
6115}
6116
6117/*!
6118 Maps the path \a path, which is in this item's coordinate system, to
6119 \a item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped path.
6120
6121 If \a item is \nullptr, this function returns the same as mapToScene().
6122
6123 \sa itemTransform(), mapToParent(), mapToScene(), mapFromItem(), {The
6124 Graphics View Coordinate System}
6125*/
6126QPainterPath QGraphicsItem::mapToItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, const QPainterPath &path) const
6127{
6128 if (item)
6129 return itemTransform(other: item).map(p: path);
6130 return mapToScene(path);
6131}
6132
6133/*!
6134 Maps the path \a path, which is in this item's coordinate system, to
6135 its parent's coordinate system, and returns the mapped path. If the
6136 item has no parent, \a path will be mapped to the scene's coordinate
6137 system.
6138
6139 \sa mapToScene(), mapToItem(), mapFromParent(), {The Graphics View
6140 Coordinate System}
6141*/
6142QPainterPath QGraphicsItem::mapToParent(const QPainterPath &path) const
6143{
6144 // COMBINE
6145 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
6146 return path.translated(offset: d_ptr->pos);
6147 return d_ptr->transformToParent().map(p: path);
6148}
6149
6150/*!
6151 Maps the path \a path, which is in this item's coordinate system, to
6152 the scene's coordinate system, and returns the mapped path.
6153
6154 \sa mapToParent(), mapToItem(), mapFromScene(), {The Graphics View
6155 Coordinate System}
6156*/
6157QPainterPath QGraphicsItem::mapToScene(const QPainterPath &path) const
6158{
6159 if (d_ptr->hasTranslateOnlySceneTransform())
6160 return path.translated(dx: d_ptr->sceneTransform.dx(), dy: d_ptr->sceneTransform.dy());
6161 return d_ptr->sceneTransform.map(p: path);
6162}
6163
6164/*!
6165 Maps the point \a point, which is in \a item's coordinate system, to this
6166 item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped coordinate.
6167
6168 If \a item is \nullptr, this function returns the same as mapFromScene().
6169
6170 \sa itemTransform(), mapFromParent(), mapFromScene(), transform(), mapToItem(), {The Graphics
6171 View Coordinate System}
6172*/
6173QPointF QGraphicsItem::mapFromItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, const QPointF &point) const
6174{
6175 if (item)
6176 return item->itemTransform(other: this).map(p: point);
6177 return mapFromScene(point);
6178}
6179
6180/*!
6181 \fn QPointF QGraphicsItem::mapFromItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, qreal x, qreal y) const
6182 \overload
6183
6184 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapFromItem(\a item,
6185 QPointF(\a x, \a y)).
6186*/
6187
6188/*!
6189 Maps the point \a point, which is in this item's parent's coordinate
6190 system, to this item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped
6191 coordinate.
6192
6193 \sa mapFromItem(), mapFromScene(), transform(), mapToParent(), {The Graphics
6194 View Coordinate System}
6195*/
6196QPointF QGraphicsItem::mapFromParent(const QPointF &point) const
6197{
6198 // COMBINE
6199 if (d_ptr->transformData)
6200 return d_ptr->transformToParent().inverted().map(p: point);
6201 return point - d_ptr->pos;
6202}
6203
6204/*!
6205 \fn QPointF QGraphicsItem::mapFromParent(qreal x, qreal y) const
6206 \overload
6207
6208 This convenience function is equivalent to calling
6209 mapFromParent(QPointF(\a x, \a y)).
6210*/
6211
6212/*!
6213 Maps the point \a point, which is in this item's scene's coordinate
6214 system, to this item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped
6215 coordinate.
6216
6217 \sa mapFromItem(), mapFromParent(), transform(), mapToScene(), {The Graphics
6218 View Coordinate System}
6219*/
6220QPointF QGraphicsItem::mapFromScene(const QPointF &point) const
6221{
6222 if (d_ptr->hasTranslateOnlySceneTransform())
6223 return QPointF(point.x() - d_ptr->sceneTransform.dx(), point.y() - d_ptr->sceneTransform.dy());
6224 return d_ptr->sceneTransform.inverted().map(p: point);
6225}
6226
6227/*!
6228 \fn QPointF QGraphicsItem::mapFromScene(qreal x, qreal y) const
6229 \overload
6230
6231 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapFromScene(QPointF(\a
6232 x, \a y)).
6233*/
6234
6235/*!
6236 Maps the rectangle \a rect, which is in \a item's coordinate system, to
6237 this item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped rectangle as a
6238 polygon.
6239
6240 If \a item is \nullptr, this function returns the same as mapFromScene()
6241
6242 \sa itemTransform(), mapToItem(), mapFromParent(), transform(), {The Graphics View Coordinate
6243 System}
6244*/
6245QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapFromItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, const QRectF &rect) const
6246{
6247 if (item)
6248 return item->itemTransform(other: this).map(a: rect);
6249 return mapFromScene(rect);
6250}
6251
6252/*!

6254 \since 4.3

6257*/
6258
6259/*!
6260 Maps the rectangle \a rect, which is in this item's parent's coordinate
6261 system, to this item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped rectangle
6262 as a polygon.
6263

6265 System}
6266*/
6267QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapFromParent(const QRectF &rect) const
6268{
6269 // COMBINE
6270 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
6271 return rect.translated(p: -d_ptr->pos);
6272 return d_ptr->transformToParent().inverted().map(a: rect);
6273}
6274
6275/*!
6276 \fn QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapFromParent(qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h) const
6277 \since 4.3
6278
6279 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapFromItem(QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h)).
6280*/
6281
6282/*!
6283 Maps the rectangle \a rect, which is in this item's scene's coordinate
6284 system, to this item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped rectangle
6285 as a polygon.

6288 System}
6289*/
6290QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapFromScene(const QRectF &rect) const
6291{
6292 if (d_ptr->hasTranslateOnlySceneTransform())
6293 return rect.translated(dx: -d_ptr->sceneTransform.dx(), dy: -d_ptr->sceneTransform.dy());
6294 return d_ptr->sceneTransform.inverted().map(a: rect);
6295}
6296
6297/*!
6298 \fn QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapFromScene(qreal x, qreal y, qreal w, qreal h) const
6299 \since 4.3
6300
6301 This convenience function is equivalent to calling mapFromScene(QRectF(\a x, \a y, \a w, \a h)).
6302*/
6303
6304/*!
6305 Maps the polygon \a polygon, which is in \a item's coordinate system, to
6306 this item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped polygon.
6307

6309
6310 \sa itemTransform(), mapToItem(), mapFromParent(), transform(), {The
6311 Graphics View Coordinate System}
6312*/

6314{
6315 if (item)
6316 return item->itemTransform(other: this).map(a: polygon);
6317 return mapFromScene(polygon);
6318}
6319
6320/*!
6321 Maps the polygon \a polygon, which is in this item's parent's coordinate
6322 system, to this item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped polygon.
6323
6324 \sa mapToParent(), mapToItem(), transform(), {The Graphics View Coordinate
6325 System}
6326*/
6327QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapFromParent(const QPolygonF &polygon) const
6328{
6329 // COMBINE
6330 if (!d_ptr->transformData)
6331 return polygon.translated(offset: -d_ptr->pos);
6332 return d_ptr->transformToParent().inverted().map(a: polygon);
6333}
6334
6335/*!
6336 Maps the polygon \a polygon, which is in this item's scene's coordinate
6337 system, to this item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped polygon.
6338
6339 \sa mapToScene(), mapFromParent(), transform(), {The Graphics View Coordinate
6340 System}
6341*/
6342QPolygonF QGraphicsItem::mapFromScene(const QPolygonF &polygon) const
6343{
6344 if (d_ptr->hasTranslateOnlySceneTransform())
6345 return polygon.translated(dx: -d_ptr->sceneTransform.dx(), dy: -d_ptr->sceneTransform.dy());
6346 return d_ptr->sceneTransform.inverted().map(a: polygon);
6347}
6348
6349/*!
6350 Maps the path \a path, which is in \a item's coordinate system, to
6351 this item's coordinate system, and returns the mapped path.
6352

6354
6355 \sa itemTransform(), mapFromParent(), mapFromScene(), mapToItem(), {The
6356 Graphics View Coordinate System}
6357*/
6358QPainterPath QGraphicsItem::mapFromItem(const QGraphicsItem *item, const QPainterPath &path) const
6359{
